title: 6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car
subTitle: You don't do any of these things. Right?
promoTitle: 6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car
promoTeaserSmall: You don't do any of these things. Right?
promoTeaser: You don't do any of these things. Right?
keywords: 6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car
metaTitle: 6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: You don't do any of these things in the car, do you?

pageElements.text: Sick of being warned about distracted driving? Not to worry—although we agree that you should put down the cheeseburger and the cell phone and watch the road whenever you’re driving. This is not one of those stories. This time, we’re warning you about the everyday habits you and your passengers have probably picked up, probably without considering how dangerous they are.

Let’s face it: an automobile is a giant, heavyweight projectile, and you’re sitting inside it, going 70 mph. Take a few minutes and consider these six rules that you should immediately adopt for yourself and your passengers.

1. No legs up on the dashboard.

Airbags and seatbelts are designed to save you, but you compromise that with something as mundane as improper and reclined seating positions. It’s tempting, especially on a long drive, for the front-seat passenger to kick off his or her shoes and stretch the legs across the dash. It’s also dangerous. The airbag that’s under the dashboard is designed to deploy extremely quickly —in 1/20 of a second, at speeds up to 200 mph, according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. When it does, it’s designed to protect a passenger sitting in the upright position with a seatbelt on. If that bag deploys in an accident and encounters your legs, it is likely to push them back into your body, hard. If you’ve seen the cautionary tale of Canadian college student Bethany Benson (http://www.caa.ca/feet-on-the-dash/), whose life and health were seriously transformed when that happened to her, you will keep your feet on the floor where they belong.

2. No seatbelt tucked under the arm or behind the back.

Short women and teenagers are frequently guilty of this. Parents are guilty of letting the teenagers get away with it. The National Institutes of Health published a study linking this practice to deaths from “lacerations of the liver, spleen, intestines, mesentery, diaphragm, and aorta, and spine injury” in accidents. The seatbelt is designed to lock in place in an accident, and you don’t want that sudden “grab” to hit you in the internal organs. There’s even a medical condition called “seatbelt syndrome” to describe the damage that can happen if your seatbelt is not strapped across your body in the correct position.

So keep the seatbelt diagonally across the center of your chest, away from your neck, with the lap belt low on the hips and below the stomach. If the fit’s not right, adjust the seat instead. 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3612840

3. Don’t sit too close to the airbag.

If you’re driving, sit at least 10 inches away from the steering wheel, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) recommends. How to get there? If you have a tilting and telescoping steering wheel, move it back and tilt it down. Slide your seat back, recline the seatback. While we’re at it, take a few minutes to think about how you are positioned in the driver’s seat. AAA recommends you position yourself so that your line of sight is three inches above the steering wheel for best visibility. http://seniordriving.aaa.com/improve-your-driving-skills/prepare-drive/your-bodys-fit-vehicle

image.altText: 04 Not Buckled Credit Flickr Lars Plougmann

pageElements.text:
4. No riding in the back seat unbelted—and no allowing others to do that.

CBS “60 Minutes” correspondent Bob Simon was killed this way in February, riding in the back of a Lincoln Town Car taxi in Manhattan. It may be somewhat safer to ride in the back seat, but you still need to be strapped in so the airbags, which increasingly provide full coverage to back-seat passengers, can do their job. It’s tempting to let your back-seat riders wander around in back, or even unstrap and lie down across the back seat. Don’t let them. Ever. credit: flickr/Lars Plougmann

5. No loose objects rolling around on the floor or seats.

The trunk or rear storage compartment of your vehicle is there to carry things. Take the extra 30 seconds to put the packages you haven’t mailed yet, the umbrellas and used coffee cups into the back. They don’t look too scary now, but in a crash….check out this German video for a mental picture you won't forget anytime soon.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Q1jj4NAzfHQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

6. No smoking a cigarette or pipe while you drive.

Well, don’t do that in the first place, but if the airbag deploys while you’re lighting up, you’ll be wearing it. It’s also a form of distracted driving, since the fiddling with lighters, ashes, and disposal all take attention of the road. And aside from the damage you could do to yourself if you drop the lit smoke in an accident, secondhand smoke is a proven risk to everybody who rides in the car with you. Don’t do it.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/VgP3jVkYpVQ" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

2016 Buick Enclave AWD-Premium

Type: Seven- or eight-passenger, mid-size front-wheel-drive luxury sport-utility vehicle
Trim levels: Convenience, Leather, Premium, Tuscan Edition
Base price: $49,515 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $53,630
Engine: 3.6-liter V-6, 288 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/22 mpg highway (AWD); 17/24 mpg (FWD)
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars
Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: not yet rated (2015 Enclave was scored as Good in four categories)
You might also be considering (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Acura MDX ($43,785)
2015 BMW X5 ($54,895)
2016 Hyundai Santa Fe ($31,295)
Fun-O-Meter: 6.5

I ran this photo on the Jean Knows Cars Facebook page recently, showing the view by night through a 2016 Buick Enclave’s windshield. The comments were surprising and many. Was it the strip of turquoise mood lighting that wraps all the way around the dash? Perhaps. It’s a slightly edgy look for what continues to be a pretty traditionalist vehicle, despite all advertising to the contrary. And rightly so, because lots of buyers want that.

Do you know how many people—women and men—love, love, love their Buick Enclave? It’s a strong emotion for a big, old school sport-utility vehicle first introduced in 2008 that hasn’t changed since 2013. At least, not that you’d notice looking at it sitting curbside. Not unless you can spot the new nineteen-inch wheels, a standard feature on this Enclave Limited.

If you’ve been loving your old Enclave for too long, and you can’t stop now...that’s okay. Your lovely, comfy seven-passenger SUV hasn’t changed that much; the 2016 model is a lot like the 2013, only better. Joke all you want about Buicks being for the middle-aged and older buyer, but this is a car company that appreciates and honors continuity, respects tradition, and has figured out how to integrate the latest technology into a surprisingly timeless, classic package.

The Enclave is sold in three trim levels and in front- or all-wheel-drive versions, all with a 3.6-liter V-6 and a six-speed automatic transmission. As befits an SUV that’s squarely in the cushy category, there are lots of luxury and semi-luxury features on board. Even the base Convenience package (base price, $39,990 including destination charge) has a rearview camera, SiriusXM satellite radio, 4G LTE Wi-Fi, remote start, and a power liftgate as standard. However, it’s the only model of Enclave available only as front-wheel drive, not all-wheel drive. The midlevel Leather package ($44,585) adds eight-way power adjustable front seats with—you guessed it—leather trim, plus a heated, wood-trimmed steering wheel, nineteen-inch aluminum wheels, and a few of the best active safety features: rear park assist, side blind zone alert, and rear cross-traffic alert.

The top-end Limited package ($48,440), the model that we tested, adds forward collision alert, lane departure warning, heated and cooled front seats, a premium Bose sound system, and a set of 19-inch chrome-clad aluminum wheels (20-inch wheels are optional). Buick is also tarting up the SUV a little with the new-for-2016 Tuscan Edition, which has a bronze theme; the 20-inch chrome-clad wheels have bronze accents, and the traditional Buick “waterfall” grille is bronze.
Its voice recognition speaks like a human and can recognize my occasionally grating Michigan accent, a very special blend of nasal, flat-vowel, duck-quacking disharmony.

Now, speaking about that “latest technology” thing. Navigation systems are becoming as common as air conditioning, and they can be just as fiddly to get right. There’s nothing remotely fiddly about the Enclave’s excellent Intellilink system. I don’t use the word “perfect” too often, but in this 2016 Enclave, the nav system is perfect. It has voice recognition that speaks like a human and can recognize my occasionally grating Michigan accent, a very special blend of nasal, flat-vowel, duck-quacking disharmony. But it knows me. Speak the address in one sentence; the Enclave’s nav system will deal with it.

It also has in-car 4G LTE Wi-Fi, which is new for 2016 in the Enclave as it expands across the General Motors lineup. This is a controversial add-on in the Jean Knows Cars offices. Some of us love the idea of being able to stream movies and surf the Internet on a road trip—only while riding as a passenger, of course. Others feel that the monthly data charge you’ll incur after the first three months of ownership is not necessary as long as you’ve got a smartphone with a data plan. I tend to think that in-car wireless is something we’ll be taking for granted within a few years. Of course, in the Enclave, it is teamed with GM’s OnStar services, which is all the better.

Having said all that, the tiny carryover infotainment screen is a disappointment in an age when customers seem to want something as big as an iPad. This one is 6.5 inches, even on the optional top-end infotainment package with navigation ($1,395) and rear-seat entertainment ($2,035), which has dual DVD-player screens in the second row that are even bigger, at seven inches. Why do the eight-year-olds in the second row get better screens than their parents in the front? I ask. Spoken like a true childless DINK (double income, no kids).

As for the kids in the back, one key to the Enclave’s popularity is that you can get it in seven-passenger or eight-passenger versions, and the second row of seats have a handle (Buick calls it SmartSlide) that lets you fold and slide the seats, which makes it easier for people to get into the third row. That’s the kind of versatility that explains why so many people who might have bought a minivan in the past are going for the Buick Enclave instead.

There’s no doubt that you have many, many choices when it comes to an SUV this size: almost two dozen of them, in fact. If you’re trying to figure out why a Buick should make it to your short list, think about this. For two years in a row, Buick has been number one in the J.D. Power Customer Service Index among twenty mass-market brands. The Enclave doesn’t have the cachet of a Mercedes-Benz GL-Class or the cult following that models from Honda (Pilot) and Hyundai (Santa Fe) can call on, but it offers an exquisitely cossetting magic-carpet ride. So, if tradition and truly fabulous comfort appeal to you, this is one SUV you should not overlook.

title: 2016 Acura RLX
subTitle: On technology alone, don't overlook this luxury sedan.
promoTeaserSmall: On technology alone, don't overlook this luxury sedan.
promoTeaser: On technology alone, don't overlook this luxury sedan.
metaTitle: 2016 Acura RLX
metaDescription: On technology alone, don't overlook this luxury sedan.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel drive luxury sedan
Price range: $55,370 - $66,870
Trim levels: RLX, RLX Sport Hybrid SH-AWD
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 310 horsepower; hybrid three-motor system with lithium-ion battery, combined 377 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic or seven-speed dual-clutch (Sport Hybrid)
Fuel economy: RLX: 20 mpg city/31 mpg highway; RLX Sport Hybrid: 28/32
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus
Our favorite standard feature: Navigation
Notable standard features on this model: Jewel Eye LED headlights, heated side mirrors, rain-sensing windshield wipers, tri-zone automatic climate control, Milano leather-trimmed interior, power front seats, forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control
Notable options on this model: Krell audio system, heated front seats, front and rear parking sensors, heated steering wheel
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Cadillac CTS, Mercedes-Benz E-Class

The RLX stepped up its tech game for 2016, and luckily many of the bells and whistles now come standard. Acura has the slightly frustrating practice of distinguishing between models based on packages, so for the RLX there are the Navigation, Technology, and Advance packages. For 2016, the company has dropped two packages, and Navigation is now the base model. Now that we have that cleared up, let’s talk standard features. Navigation, rain-sensing wipers, power seats, and forward collision warning are included on all package levels, which is rather incredible. The options also include some cool features, such as front and rear parking sensors and a heated steering wheel. The RLX’s 3.5-liter V-6 produces 310 horsepower, and if you opt for the Sport Hybrid, a three-motor system with lithium-ion battery will deliver 377 horsepower. Despite all the power under the hood, this vehicle received five stars from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and was named a Top Safety Pick Plus, the highest accolade from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. There is no manual transmission available, but a seven-speed dual-clutch is found on the Sport Hybrid model. The RLX delivers luxury and performance without a BMW or Mercedes logo on the grille. You can decide whether that’s a good or bad thing.
New for 2016: AcuraWatch expands scope and content of safety and driver assistive technologies

More to Read:

Designer Walkaround: 2016 Acura NSX at the Detroit Auto Show (with video)

title: 2016 Lexus RX
subTitle: Some updates, but the most noticeable addition? The standout styling.
promoTeaserSmall: Some updates, but the most noticeable addition? The standout styling.
promoTeaser: Some updates, but the most noticeable addition? The standout styling.
metaTitle: 2016 Lexus RX - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Some updates, but the most noticeable addition? The standout styling.

pageElements.text:
2016 Lexus RX350 F Sport

Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Models: RX350, RX350 F Sport, RX450h (hybrid), RX450h F Sport
On-sale date: December 2015
Base price (estimated): $42,500
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 295 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway (front-wheel drive); 19/26 mpg (all-wheel drive)
My favorite standard feature: Ten-way power front seats
Option I can’t live without: Touch-free rear liftgate
Notable standard features on base model: LED headlamps; illuminated door handles, heated side mirrors with turn signal repeaters; power rear hatch; leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift lever; ten-way power front seats; reclinable rear seats; four twelve-volt outlets; two USB ports; dual zone auto climate control; foot lights; power tilting and telescoping steering column; Bluetooth; nine-speaker audio system
You might also be considering: Audi Q5, BMW X3, Land Rover Discovery, Lincoln MKX, Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class

Lexus pretty much invented the crossover class—sport-utility vehicle styling on a front-wheel-drive passenger-car platform—back in 1998, when the first RX came out. This crossover has set the pace for Toyota’s luxury division through each successive generation, accounting for a substantial proportion of Lexus sales. In 2014, this came to 34.5 percent of the brand’s sales—pretty impressive in a nine-vehicle Lexus lineup.
The RX series has never been a favorite of car-enthusiast reviewers, who have found it a little ho-hum. But it has scored well with the critics who matter most: those who vote with their checkbooks.
The traits that have propelled the RX to sales of 100,000-plus every year since launch are typical Lexus: first-rate assembly, posh interiors, smooth ride, respectable power, and quiet operation.

Those are pretty good creds, and pretty much what we’ve come to expect, given the Lexus pursuit of perfection. But if you think about it, you’ll see that something’s missing from that list of virtues. As good as it has been, the RX has never turned heads out there in the traffic stream.
So here’s generation four, and we think the Lexus stylists have resolved the anonymity issue. There’s far more character.

So here’s generation four, and we think the Lexus stylists have resolved the anonymity issue. There’s far more character in the vehicle sides, with lots of sculpting, a swoopy roofline, hunky haunches, and topping it off a great big Lexus spindle grille adorning the front, distinctly bigger than the previous generation. Whatever one may think about this Lexus cosmetic trademark—opinion seems to be either love or hate, with no middle ground—combined with the sculpted sheetmetal it helps to give the new RX much more curbside presence.

There’s more to this renewal than styling, of course. The RX has grown substantially—expanded 4.7 inches to 192.5 inches in length, on a wheelbase stretched 1.9 inches to 109.8 inches. As you’d expect, this translates as more interior volume for passengers and cargo. In the rear seat, which the design team has also enhanced by lowering the floor slightly, the seating positions are even more comfortable.

Other updates include selective stiffening of the unit body; as in all crossover SUVs, the frame and body shell are integrated. Although Lexus didn't give specifics, we encountered no chassis quivers in a day of driving the various RX models—RX350, RX450 Hybrid, and the F Sport versions of both. Lexus also invested in reducing interior noise levels, which is interesting, since the RX was already one of the more serene vehicles in this class. In any case, more than ever the RX is exemplary in terms of NVH (noise, vibration, and harshness).

A nifty addition to the new body shell is a power liftgate with an optional remote feature. Touch the Lexus logo at the rear, and the hatch pops open.

Like the current RX, the interior of the fourth generation is handsomely furnished, with several different trim combinations and a respectable list of standard features. There's a pair of audio options, a twelve-speaker Pioneer system and an even more sublime fifteen-speaker setup from Mark Levinson. Prominent among the options is a 12.3-inch color display that resides atop the center dashboard. (The regular infotainment screen is eight inches.)

The standard RX engine continues to be a 3.5-liter V-6, but Lexus characterizes it as all new. That’s certainly true of the cylinder heads, which now accommodate direct fuel injection, yielding greater efficiency and more power. EPA ratings gain 1 mpg in the city for front- and all-wheel-drive versions, 20 mpg in the city and 28 mpg on the highway for the front-wheel-drive model and 19/26 mpg for the AWD model. (Incidentally, Lexus is now saying AWD means "all-weather drive.")

Horsepower climbs from 270 to 295 horsepower, which matches the combined output of the current RX450h, a gasoline-electric hybrid. The powertrain of the 450h, for its part, doesn’t change much, augmenting power of the 3.5-liter gasoline engine with an electric motor boost to the front axle in front-drive versions, and another at the rear in AWD versions. EPA ratings are 31/30 mpg for the front-wheel-drive hybrid, 30/28 with AWD.

As with the current RX, the standard V-6 is paired with a smooth eight-speed automatic transmission that features paddle shifters in F Sport models. The 450h transmits power via a continuously variable transmission (CVT), which continues to be a little tedious when the driver suddenly calls for maximum thrust as the transmission works to catch up with the engine.
The F Sport version has a firmer setup with adaptive shock absorbers and multiple operating modes, giving the steering a little more sense of precision.

The Lexus chassis engineers have made alterations to the suspension setup, softening the spring rates but stiffening other components to reduce body roll in cornering without compromising ride quality. The ride is still luxurious in most trim levels, particularly the standard RX with eighteen-inch wheels (higher trim levels have twenty-inch wheels). The F Sport version has a firmer setup with adaptive shock absorbers and multiple operating modes, giving the steering a little more sense of precision. However, as with the current generation, steering is not a strong suit.

Lexus counts sixteen rivals in the RX's crossover class. Among them, you can find engines with much more punch, and several competitors that are quicker, although the RX's upgraded V-6 provides respectable acceleration; Lexus forecasts 0 to 60 mph in about seven seconds, and a little faster than that for the hybrid.

The new RX won’t reach showrooms until early December, so Lexus wasn’t ready to release 2016 prices. But pricing for the current lineup isn’t exactly at the bottom of this competitive set, ranging from about $42,000 to a little over $51,000, excluding option packages. Our fearless prediction: look for 2016 window stickers with higher numbers at the bottom line.

The 2016 Lexus RX amplifies the virtues that have made it a winner since day one: top quality, lovely interiors, quiet operation, smooth ride, and all-day comfort. Making the F Sport available in both gasoline and hybrid versions of the RX should broaden its appeal. One thing is sure: the upgraded RX can be expected to stay at the top of the Lexus sales charts.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive hybrid hatchback
Estimated price: Starting around $25,000
On-sale date: Early 2016
Trim levels: Prius, Prius Eco
Estimated fuel economy: 56 mpg city/53 mpg highway
Safety features: Toyota Safety Sense package (pre-collision alert with pedestrian detection, lane departure alert with steering assist, full-speed dynamic radar cruise control, automatic high beams)
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Chevrolet Volt ($33,995)
2016 Ford C-Max Hybrid ($25,045)
2016 Honda Civic Hybrid ($25,555)
Fun-O-Meter: We will see...

LAS VEGAS—If you want something to be seen as important, you have to make it look important. In these crazy, crazy days of cheap gas and sport-utility vehicle lust, hybrid sales have been in freefall. Toyota needed to pull out the stops to make the unveiling of the fourth-generation Prius important.

How about Vegas! How about the roof of concert venue The Linq! How about Australian alt-rockers Atlas Genius to rev up the crowd!! Let's lower it from the sky by cables and light up the night with a wild light show and laser Toyota logos on every building surrounding The Linq!
And how about we make the new Prius look really, really different?

Toyota proudly states that it has sold eight million hybrid vehicles (3.5 million of them Priuses) since it all started, back in the mid-1990s. Just by driving them, Toyota owners have 5.8 billion gallons of gasoline and avoided emitting 58 million tons of CO2 emissions.
Nothing sexier than CO2 numbers, I always say. And as for “sexy,” there’s no doubt the Prius isn’t and never has been.

Toyota is aiming to change all that with the new look and feel of the Prius, but clearly it doesn’t want or need to alienate the loyal Prius owners who have made this model a mainstay on the roads of college towns and trendy urban neighborhoods. So you’d expect it to come out not looking all that different from the somewhat awkward shape it has had since the first one came out in 1997.

Hahaha. Just kidding. It looks outrageously different—especially in the rear, which is polarizing to the nth degree. My impromptu Las Vegas rooftop poll divided opinion along gender lines: women kinda liked it, men kinda hated it. But they were journalists, bloggers, and car dealers, so never mind that. The real test will be how the radical additions to its basic wedge shape will hold up in the light of day, out on the road where it belongs.

Overall, the new Prius ticks off several of the traditional points of a pleasing design proportion—it’s longer, lower, and wider. Toyota describes its stylized side profile as “evoking an athletic shape” and “inspired by a runner in the starting blocks.” This is very close to Mazda’s description of Kodo design. Hmmm. The front has a whole lotta lights going on, a big stack on each front corner. If you stand back and take in the entire front, the overall look isn’t all that radical, but definitely fresher and more noticeable.
If you stand back and take in the entire front, the overall look isn’t all that radical, but definitely fresher and more noticeable.

The rear has even more going on, taking Cadillac’s vertical light direction further by wrapping the corners of a vestigial rear spoiler in light that arcs down so low, it almost meets the road. It begs to be photographed up close.

The last Prius I drove was Earth Day 2015. I didn’t like that it looked every one of its drab seven years. I described the gray interior as unrelenting mouse fur. The seats were uncomfortable in the extreme, and the instrument panel was centered over the center console instead of in front of the driver.

The new Prius handles most of the complaints neatly. The new interior is modern, although the shiny white plastic center console gave me pause. The seats felt great, but there it was—the center-mounted instrument panel. There’s no reason to believe any driver should get comfortable looking away from the road to read the instruments.

Which brings us to the great advances made in safety features these days, one of the best reasons to buy a new car. The 2016 Prius will have its fair share, with Toyota’s new Safety Sense active safety features on board: a pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, lane departure alert with steering assist, full-speed dynamic radar cruise control, and automatic high beams. You’ll be seeing Safety Sense across most of the Toyota lineup by the end of next year.

The proof of success will be out on the road, where the last Prius was pretty quick and delivered exceptional fuel economy, but was ungainly and uncomfortable. Fuel economy improvement is in the bag, thanks to lighter hybrid system components, better batteries, and an internal combustion engine claiming ground-breaking thermal efficiency.

Numbers aren’t being announced quite yet, although Toyota says it expects class-leading fuel economy with a 10 percent improvement over the 2015 Prius, which gets 51 mpg in the city and 48 mpg on the highway. So that would be about 55 mpg combined, better than anything that isn’t sold with a plug. Right behind this model, there will be an even more efficient Eco model.
A stiffer body and a new, more sophisticated double-wishbone rear suspension leads one to believe that the driving experience will also improve.
The Fun-O-Meter rating remains on hold until we get behind the wheel.

Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/34 mpg highway (FWD, six-speed manual transmission); 28/35 mpg (FWD, CVT); 27/32 mpg (AWD, CVT)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS):
Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Multi-angle rearview camera (with guide lines on EX and EX-L Navi)
Notable standard features on this model: LED brake lights, intermittent rear wiper, tilting and telescoping steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Honda Lane Watch active safety package, power tilting moonroof, daytime running lamps, rear privacy glass, push-button start, heated front seats, seven-inch infotainment screen with HondaLink and Pandora compatibility (EX and EX-L Navi); roof rails, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, leather-trimmed seats, navigation system, SiriusXM HD radio (EX-L Navi only)
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Kia Soul, Jeep Renegade, Mazda CX-3, Nissan Juke

If you are interested in a subcompact—the Honda Fit, perhaps, an excellent example of the genre—but you want all-wheel drive, a higher seating position, more ground clearance, and more utility, how about the all-new 2016 Honda HR-V? That was the thinking at Honda, a company that has earned the respect and sometimes fanatic loyalty of a large number of U.S. buyers. The HR-V has some of the great features you may already know from the Fit: the second-row Magic Seat that folds into the floor and makes the interior almost incomprehensibly roomy—58.8 cubic feet of cargo space, with the rear seats down—the long list of standard equipment, and the multi-angle rearview camera, along with LaneWatch active safety tech on the upper-level EX and EX-L Navi models.

This is still a small SUV and won't be a choice for someone who is eyeing a Chevrolet Suburban or a Range Rover, but it's got the all-wheel drive, practicality, and citified appeal that Honda fans will appreciate and small-crossover buyers will find very, very attractive.

New for 2016: The HR-V is an all-new model.


More to Read:

Should You Buy It? 2016 Honda HR-V

The Buick Regal’s name says it all. This car was made for those that have royal tastes but realistic budgets. Starting at just over $27,000, your wallet will not threaten to bite your hand off after this purchase. However, do not let the price tag trick you into thinking you’re missing out on luxury. Coming standard on the Regal are OnStar,cruise control, leather-appointed seating, dual-zone automatic climate control, rearview camera, color touchscreen, and many other features. If you want to step up the class and safety even further, you can purchase packages that include features like lane change alert and adaptive cruise control. Also new this year for the Regal are the exterior colors Ebony Twilight Metallic, White Frost Metallic, Crimson Red Tintocat, and Dark Forest Green Metallic. contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2016 Kia Sorento SX Limited AWD

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive mid-size crossover
Trim levels: L, LX, EX, SX, SX Limited, Limited V6
Base price: $42,595 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $45,095
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Sportmatic
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/27 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick 2015
Competitors (prices include destination charges):
2016 Chevrolet Equinox LTZ AWD ($32,385)
2016 Honda Pilot Touring AWD ($43,700)
2016 Mazda CX-5 Grand Touring AWD ($30,350)
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cc1AsxDkPX4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Fun-O-Meter: 7

There’s nothing that says New! Improved! like, well, a new and improved vehicle. Or an entire new and improved car company. And isn’t it about time we move on with Kia, away from the darkness of the bad, old days of the most affordable, least desirable, throwaway cars on the planet? Because Kia turned the corner on quality, reliability, and desirability an entire decade ago. If you are still looking down your nose at this car company, you haven’t kept up with the news.

It’s not that I don’t understand where the bad vibe came from. Looking for a car for my brother, I used eBay Motors in 2008 to find a super clean 2004 Kia Rio with 48,000 miles on the odometer. As I took delivery, the very sweet business owner handed me the keys and said, “If I have one piece of advice for these disposable cars, it’s change the oil often.” Yes, she said that, and it was good advice, too. I wish she’d also told me that I’d need to change out the timing belt at around 60,000 miles to prevent the engine from exploding.

Despite that dire warning, I would like to say that my brother more than tripled that Rio’s age and mileage over the course of the next three years with no massive repairs. The body was worse for the wear, but he had a heavy hand in hastening its delivery to Charity Motors.

By the time I bought that used Rio, Kia was already turning the corner. In fact, the new Rio was so brilliant, it joined the Optima on Automobile Magazine’s short list of 2012 All-Stars candidates. By then, Kias were well made and pretty fun to drive. More than that, they suddenly looked bold and fresh, a feat delivered seemingly overnight by Kia’s new design boss, former Audi chief designer Peter Schreyer, so impressive that he was a shoo-in for Automobile Magazine’s 2012 Man of the Year.
Kia hasn’t looked back, constantly refining and adding to its lineup of quirky funmobiles, cute utes, and smart-looking sedans, and pushing the envelope upmarket as it goes.

Right here, right now, I am looking at one of the most luscious crossovers in the mid-size class, the 2016 Sorento. Every bit of the exterior has been thoughtfully reshaped, in some areas more than others. Complex headlamp units tuck into a tidy new grille, and pockets for the foglamps are filled in our test car with a grid of four large LED lights.

It had better be as good as it looks, because the completely new 2016 Kia Sorento has revamped its pricing to a level that might take your breath away. If you were straggling in to the Kia dealership with your bag full of pennies, you’d be scurrying right back out. Our test car, the SX Limited AWD, is just a step below the most expensive Sorento. It checks out at $45,095 including destination ($895) and one $2,500 optional Technology package of advanced safety features like forward collision warning, lane departure warning, smart cruise control, and a few extras with them, like a very trick surround-view monitor.

But if you’re a good shopper, you’ll take a closer look with your clipboard in hand, and pull up the exceptional Kia Build & Price configurator on your laptop with its excellent descriptions and images of trim levels and features. The Sorento is available in five-passenger and seven-passenger versions. There is one versatile six-speed automatic transmission and a choice of three engines—a 3.3-liter V-6 and two four-cylinders, including a brand-new, 240-horsepower 2.0-liter turbo, which you can only get with the five-passenger Sorento. If you don’t need all-wheel drive, take $1,800 off the price.

The buying experience is almost a one-price deal, with a long list of great features that are typically extra-cost options on competitors: for example, the gorgeous nappa leather interior trim, which is standard on Limited models. Our test car’s nappa leather trim was maroon, with silvered grey leather seating perforated in a delicate chevron pattern. I had to touch it every time I got in.
Overall, the Sorento offers one of the most luxurious and meticulously detailed interior designs in this segment. It’s also slightly bigger with a second row that splits and folds flat.

The instruments are bright, clear, and gathered in a neat binnacle in front of the driver. There’s a long menu of screens with all the must-have features of the modern luxury vehicle, including an 8.0-inch infotainment screen with voice-activated navigation, app interfaces, and Sirius Traffic. The entire driver interface is exquisitely thought out and executed. Screens are large, crisp, and useful. The rearview camera, standard on all but the base L model, displays a handy live image of what’s behind the Sorento whenever you put the transmission in Reverse. There’s also a “footprint” showing the width of the bumper to really let you get your bearings. It especially came in handy when parallel parking in front of my office in a space about a foot away from an endless stream of semis roaring past. I like to hug the curb without tearing up the wheels, something that is more easily accomplished with the Sorento’s mega camera view.

This is by no means a sport vehicle, although the 2016 model is better to drive thanks to a more rigid structure, high-strength steel, and a stiffer suspension. It’s a luxury vehicle—and one that shines like a diamond.

J.D. Power now ranks Kia second only to Porsche in initial quality. And if that still doesn’t convince you to have a look at the Sorento, there’s still the best powertrain warranty in the business—ten years/10,000 miles—backing it up.
That’s putting your money where your mouth is.

pageElements.text:
2016 Infiniti QX50 RWD

Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Trim levels: QX50, QX50 AWD
Base price: $35,445 (rear-wheel drive); $36,845 (all-wheel drive) (prices include destination charge)
This car: $43,095
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 325 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic with manual shift mode
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/24 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Competitors (prices include destination charges):
2016 Audi Q5 2.0 TFSI ($41,825)
2016 Acura RDX ($36,190)
2016 Lexus NX200 ($36,360)
2016 Porsche Macan S ($53,595)

Fun-O-Meter: 8.5

My husband, a.k.a. The Laugh Riot, claimed once that he’d written me a song he titled, “I Might Be Old, But I’m New to You.” That would be apropos of the 2016 Infiniti QX50, which you may have missed (or ignored) when it was called the EX35 and then the EX37.

It’s also a song title that implies the distinct possibility that being old isn’t necessarily a bad thing. My husband, for instance, is the best thing ever. As it turns out, the QX50 has every bit of the old EX37 sparkle, only some remnants of now dated technology, and quite a lot of notable improvements.

You don’t have to squint at its curvaceous profile to see the eight-year-old crossover before you. It looked fresh back then, it still looks interesting, and if you’re sharp about these things, you’ll see that the QX50 sits a tad higher (0.8 inch, for 6.9 inches of ground clearance), and that it’s more than a bit longer. That little 4.5-inch stretcharoo does wonders for its overall proportions, not to mention its cabin volume, which gained 8.3 cubic feet of precious space.

Lack of space, especially in the rear seat, was a real problem with the EX37. Infiniti points proudly to the 2016 QX50’s extra 3.9 inches of legroom back there. Hmm. I have a thirty-four-inch inseam, and my driving partner, KABC automotive reporter and nutball Dave Kuntz, is probably 6'5". We fit comfortably in the front, but I could barely wedge the Dutch apple pie I bought from the Julian Pie Company during our test drive in the mountains above San Diego on the floor between the front and back seats. My feet are longer than that pie box.
Okay, so I have huge feet, and maybe you don’t.

The QX also got a face lift with Infiniti’s latest design statement—a new “double arch” grille with bold grating that forms a strong backdrop for the large chrome Infiniti badge. The headlamps are also new (as so many are these days) and puts forth an interesting light “signature” at night. New alloy wheels complete the exterior tailoring.

Our test car’s nineteen-inch split five-spoke wheels are part of the optional Deluxe Touring package ($2,400) which also includes HID xenon headlights, a trick coat hanger built into the back of the driver headrest, and power-up second-row seats that you can control from the center console, the first in its class.
The leather-swathed, wood-trimmed, all-power-everything interior is lovely and cosseting, but it had no impact on the Fun-O-Meter.
If you can afford truly bad fuel economy (17 mpg city/24 mpg highway), you will be rewarded with an outstanding display of power and might. The V-6 is a heart of gold.

It’s the engine I swoon over: a 3.7-liter V-6 that sits behind the front wheel axis (providing exceptional balance and poise on our mountain test route) and is another carryover from the EX37. If you can afford truly bad fuel economy (17 mpg city/24 mpg highway), you will be rewarded with an outstanding display of power and might. Not only is horsepower rated at 325, the torque (which provides the thrust that throws you back in the seat when you stand on the throttle) is a substantial 267 pound-feet. It’s mated to a seven-speed automatic transmission with a manual shift mode that includes automatic rev matching for quick and satisfying downshifts. It is like magic. The V-6 is a heart of gold, and we had many opportunities to test it on the twisty roads leading up to that unbelievable pie.

I honestly don’t remember the EX37 being this much of a riot to drive. It’s always more fun to drive a rear-wheel-drive car, and the QX50 was no exception. Note that I said car. The steering is much more responsive than you would expect from a sub-$50,000 crossover, and the sophisticated suspension is what you would find under a sports car. No real surprise, then, that this platform also underpins the Q50 sedan and Nissan’s 370Z.

There just aren’t that many hot rod utility vehicles among the small luxury crossover competition—and it’s the fastest, hottest crossover growth segment today. According to Infiniti product planning director Keith St. Clair, small luxury crossovers may be even bigger than sedans, no surprise.
Our test QX50 was loaded up with every single option package, and it still came in under $44,000.

You would have to head pretty far up in the crossover food chain to find one better. The mighty (and mighty popular) Porsche Macan is the first one to come to mind. It’s base price is $53,595, including destination charge. Compare that with the QX50’s base price of $35,445 for the rear-wheel-drive model ($36,845 for all-wheel drive), which Infiniti noted was $550 less than the EX37 and includes $1,750 in added standard features. Our test QX50 was loaded up with every single option package—the one with all the hot safety tech, the luxury comfort stuff, the sweet Bose system, the navigation, XM Traffic, and the Around-View Monitor with the first vehicle that can detect moving objects around the perimeter, as well as illuminated kickplates—all for an additional $8,090. It still came in under $44,000.

This is the new Infiniti, one that is hellbent on enjoying selling some cars for a change. Buoyed by twelve consecutive months of record sales (up 10 percent in the U.S and 14 percent globally), Infiniti is embarking on an ambitious run of new products over the next couple of years. New products will replace current Qs (the cars), and you can expect brand-new QX models (the crossovers).

Johan de Nysschen, who came from Audi to revamp Infiniti, used to say about Audis that he didn’t want to see one in every driveway because it would erode their aura of exclusivity. At Infiniti, exclusivity was not his priority. He moved global headquarters to Hong Kong, expanded sales around the globe, and launched production plants in Mexico, the U.K, and China (where Infiniti’s booming sales are second only to Porsche). He flew the coop in 2014 after two years to head up Cadillac, leaving Infiniti to make sense of it all.
If this new QX50 is an indicator, the Nissan luxury division is making plenty of sense.

Based on the concepts we’ve seen at the world’s auto shows and in the backroom of Infiniti design, the aura of exclusivity is all there. Luckily for its customers, the affordability goes along with it. Get them while they’re this hot.

title: Driver's Ed Books for Parents
subTitle: Two books by dads who want to equip parents with a better way to help new drivers.
promoTeaserSmall: Two books by dads who want to equip parents with a better way to help new drivers.
promoTeaser: Two books by dads who want to equip parents with a better way to help new drivers.
metaTitle: Driver's Ed Books for Parents - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Two books by dads who want to equip parents with a better way to help new drivers.

pageElements.text: You think teething is bad. You think middle school is awkward for both you and your kid. All true. But, for sheer terror, nothing matches the day your teenager starts driving the family car.

Now it's not that you don't trust your teenager. But you feel so....helpless handing over those keys, hoping but not quite convinced that the driver's ed class has educated him or her enough for what's out there.

Two dads have addressed that feeling by publishing their own slim paperbacks to help parents help their kids. Either (or both) of these books can give you the boost you need to supplement the driver education classes in which your child is—you hope—paying close attention, with practical advice and tips you may not have thought of.
Oh, and either one is good to hand to the kid as well.

What Teenage Drivers Don't Know: The Unwritten Rules of the Road

by John Harmata and Paul Zientarski
$9.95 from Lake Effect Publishing

Harmata had a serious scare when he was eighteen. It involved black ice and a 360-degree spinout. Uninjured but more than a little freaked out, he spent the next three decades taking driving seriously. He and driver education program chairman Paul Zientarski have catalogued the most common dangers on the road in this seventy-two-page manual. Those range from country road hazards to driving through fog, with anecdotes and practical advice for handling each one.
Reading this book is like having your own dad sitting in the passenger's seat, passing on a lifetime of well-earned expertise.

If you (and/or your teenager) aren't a little nervous after reading through this book's laundry list of dangers, you aren't paying attention. But don't stop there; go on to the very useful tips that follow. There's an entire section on what to do after an accident, for example, including how to behave in court, and another on parking lot etiquette and technique. It's like having your own dad sitting in the passenger's seat, passing on a lifetime of well-earned expertise.

Harmata wins bonus points for his chapter titled, "Why Teens Should Never Let Friends Borrow Their Vehicle." Those bonus points probably won't come from your teenager, but he is right, and his six reasons (including #5, "never assume a friend is going to admit to having received a parking ticket while using your vehicle") will give parents the ammunition they might need to convince their kids.

Not So Fast: Parenting Your Teen through the Dangers of Driving

by Tim Hollister
$12.95 from IPG Books

This book addresses teen driving from a psychological perspective, helping you as a parent understand why teenagers think and drive the way they do, and giving you ideas about how to approach your own child in a productive, helpful way around driving. The author's inspiration comes from the most tragic source: his own son died in a one-car accident less than a year after getting his license.

Hollister did everything right. His kid was driving a Volvo. He took an approved driver education course and had more than the required amount of on-the-road practice. He wasn't texting, under the influence of alcohol or drugs, or otherwise breaking the law. He just lost control of the car on a curve, because of inexperience.

Hollister starts there. Using the latest ideas about how teenagers' brains develop, and without overstating or trying to frighten the reader, he gives parents a lot to think about. "Understand and accept the dangers of teen driving as your baseline" is the take-away message, and no matter how convenient it is to hand teens the car keys so they can get themselves to hockey practice from now on, it's an essential message for parents.
This book lays out the Teen Driving Agreement idea in complete detail, giving you a road map that will actually let you succeed at it.

What's most useful about this book is its plan for teens and parents to work together to improve those safety odds. You may have seen various ads and public service announcements suggesting you have a Teen Driving Agreement with your child. This book lays it out in complete detail, giving you a road map that will actually let you succeed at it.

The bonus in Not So Fast is its advice on mentoring other people's teenagers, including the best way to talk to other parents about their children's driving. It also makes suggestions for dealing with your local schools and becoming a safe driving activist in your community. Hollister is obviously deeply affected by this issue, and his resulting thorough coverage of the challenges of teen driving makes useful reading for every parent.

images.caption: Chapter heading from Not So Fast, by Tim Hollister.
Selection from What Teenage Drivers Don't Know, by Harmata and Zientarski.

Fuel economy: 2.8-liter turbo-diesel, RWD: 28 mpg city/31 mpg highway; 2.5-liter four-cylinder: 22/26-27 mpg; 3.6-liter, V-6: 21/26 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good (moderate overlap front test only)
Our favorite standard feature: Hidden under-seat storage
Notable standard features on this model: OnStar with 4G LTE and available Wi-Fi (LT)
Notable options on this model: Heated front seats, forward collision alert, lane departure warning
You might also be considering: GMC Canyon, Honda Ridgeline, Nissan Frontier, Toyota Tacoma

The Chevrolet Colorado is only a year old, and this sibling to the GMC Canyon is already a definite success. Named Motor Trend Truck of the Year in both 2015 and 2016, it has also garnered praise for its cost to own, resale value, and technology. It's up to date in the latter, for 2016 adding Apple CarPlay smartphone connectivity. The Colorado already had OnStar with 4G LTE and a Wi-Fi hot spot in the cab—or anywhere near the Colorado if it’s turned on—that will connect seven devices. There are four USB ports, an eight-inch in-dash touchscreen display, Bluetooth, and Chevrolet's MyLink infotainment.

The available safety tech includes forward collision alert and lane departure warning. A rearview camera is standard on all models. Triple-sealed doors and thick windshield and side glass help keep exterior noises from entering the cabin. A huge center console keeps all your necessaries at hand. A secret storage compartment under the rear seat will keep your goods safe. And there are plenty of charging ports and a non-skid surface for your phone.

A new turbo-diesel engine ups towing capability from 7,000 pounds to 7,700 pounds, if you choose the rear-wheel-drive model and get the optional trailering package. It does that while achieving 31 mpg on the highway, and you won't top either of those in the mid-size truck category.

New for 2016

The Colorado was an all-new model for 2015.
A 2.8-liter turbo-diesel engine is new for 2016. Tech wise, MyLink infotainment system gets Apple CarPlay capability, and there's an enhanced driver information display in the dash.

More about the Chevrolet Colorado

2015 Chevrolet Colorado

2015 Chevrolet Colorado: L.A. Show November 20, 2013

title: 2016 Chevrolet Trax
subTitle: Urban runabout with a dash of practicality.
promoTeaserSmall: Urban runabout with a dash of practicality.
promoTeaser: Urban runabout with a dash of practicality.
metaTitle: 2016 Chevrolet Trax - JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive subcompact crossover
Price range: $21,195–$27,625
Trim levels: LS, LT, LTZ
Engines: Turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: FWD: 26 mpg city/34 mpg highway; AWD: 24/31 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in five areas; front crash prevention information not available
Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera, ten air bags
Notable standard features on this model: 4G LTE with Wi-Fi hot spot standard on all models for three months or 3 GB
Notable options on this model: Heated front seats (LTZ)
You might also be considering: Honda HR-V, Jeep Renegade, Kia Soul, Nissan Juke

The Trax is a member of a relatively new variety of vehicle, the subcompact crossover, which has a 100.3-inch wheelbase—only an inch or two longer than a Honda Fit or a Ford Fiesta—and the tall body of a sport-utility vehicle. Its mere existence is a tribute to the fact that people are increasingly swapping out their sedans for practical, high-riding vehicles with available all-wheel drive. There's no denying that the Trax, all new in 2015, is an attractive choice in this category. It's nominally a five-passenger vehicle, but you wouldn't really want to be the person in the middle of the back seat. With that back seat folded, there are 48.4 cubic feet of cargo space. For comparison purposes, the Honda CR-V, a more traditionally sized compact crossover, offers 70.9 cubic feet with its rear seat down. So the Trax may not be the big-stuff hauler, if that's what you are looking for, but if you want an adorable urban runabout, it has much to recommend it.

For example, there is a standard rearview camera, available park assist, and a seven-inch touchscreen with OnStar and 4G LTE with a wireless hot spot on board. Siri Eyes Free, too, which is a novelty in this price range.

New for 2016

The Trax was all new in 2015.
There are four new metallic paint colors: Crimson, Sable, Cyber Gray, and Champagne Silver.

More about the Chevrolet Trax

title: 2016 Chevrolet Volt
subTitle: Better-looking and yet greener.
promoTeaserSmall: Better-looking and yet greener.
promoTeaser: Better-looking and yet greener.
metaTitle: 2016 Chevrolet Volt - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Better-looking and yet greener.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive gasoline-electric hybrid compact hatchback
Price range: $33,995—$39,830
Trim levels: LT, Premier
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 180 horsepower, and two electric motors
Transmission:Electrically variable direct drive
Fuel economy: 42 mpg city/highway combined, 106 MPGe
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Regen(eration) on Demand
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, heated leather seats, leather-wrapped steering wheel, 8.0-inch infotainment screen, Bose eight-speaker premium audio, five-year OnStar service
Notable options on this model: Chevrolet MyLink with navigation ($495), Driver Confidence 1 package: blind spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, lane departure alert ($495); Driver Confidence 2 package: lane-keeping assist, low-speed automatic braking, forward collision alert, auto-dimming headlights ($495)
You might also be considering: BMW i3, Ford C-Max, Lexus CT Hybrid, Nissan Leaf, Toyota Prius and Prius V

It has been on the market since 2010, but this year Chevrolet has rolled out an all-new model. The 2016 Chevrolet Volt looks a whole lot more like a "normal" five-passenger car and less like some kind of futuristic fantasy of the 1990s, and that is a very good thing. It wasn't a big seller in its original incarnation (fewer than 80,000 sold in the five years on the market), even though it has the advantage over plug-in hybrids of being seamless, switching from all-electric to gasoline power with no human intervention. On all-electric power, you can go 53 miles, and it has a 420-mile range between trips to the gas station. That's up 40 miles from the previous model.

The 2016 Chevrolet Volt has a 20 percent larger battery pack (which lives under the floor near the center of the car) and a more powerful, yet lighter gasoline engine. The car as a whole weighs 200 pounds less than the outgoing model, a good thing if you're interested in fuel economy—and surely you are, if you're considering the Volt. It also has more space in the back seat—you can even seat five now, but only in a pinch. The Volt isn't luxurious inside, but it's comfortable, and you can geek out on the mileage and fuel economy details on readouts. A steering wheel paddle switch called Regen on Demand increases the Volt's battery regeneration to extend electric range.
The 2016 Volt has limited availability; for a full nationwide rollout, you'll wait until the 2017 model year, Chevrolet says.

More about the 2016 Chevrolet Volt

For a full report, see our October 7, 2015, review of the 2016 Chevrolet Volt Premier.

title: 2017 Hyundai Elantra
subTitle: One look tells you this new sedan will be desirable amid tough competition.
promoTeaserSmall: One look tells you this new sedan will be desirable amid tough competition.
promoTeaser: One look tells you this new sedan will be desirable amid tough competition.
metaTitle: 2017 Hyundai Elantra - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Hyundai at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: One look tells you this new sedan will be desirable amid tough competition.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Release date: January 2016
Estimated price range: $18,250 - $24,500
Competes against: Chevrolet Cruze, Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Kia Forte, Mazda 3, Nissan Sentra, Toyota Corolla, Volkswagen Jetta
What's most interesting: Mid-size roominess in a compact sedan

What do consumers want from their compact cars? Well, everything, of course, but roominess is right near the top of the list, and that’s one of several strong suits for the sixth generation of Hyundai’s Elantra sedan.

The Elantra is a little bigger than the current car, a dimensional increase that shows to particularly good advantage in the rear seat. Although it’s nominally a compact, the EPA goes by interior volume, which bumps the Elantra up to mid-size (where it joins the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla). Increased use of high-strength steel and massive employment of industrial adhesives add up to a 30 percent improvement in chassis rigidity, and Hyundai also cites a number of new sound-deadening measures.

There are two new engines: a 147-horsepower 2.0-liter four (standard) and a 128-hp turbocharged four, the latter paired with a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. Hyundai claims efficiency improvements over the current Elantra powertrain choices.

Like every new car rolling out these days, the Elantra has an increased inventory of safety features. Among them are lane keeping assistance, blind spot detection, rear cross-traffic and lane change assist, and a rearview camera with dynamic guidelines. (Hyundai anticipates top ratings from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration). There's also expanded infotainment technology, wrapped up in handsome packaging that looks like a small-scale version of the mid-size Sonata sedan—although not all that small.
The new Elantra will reach dealers in early January, as a 2017 model.

title: Scion C-HR Concept
subTitle: Toyota's youth brand embraces the odd in a concept that will see production next year.
promoTeaserSmall: Toyota's youth brand embraces the odd in a concept that will see production next year.
promoTeaser: Toyota's youth brand embraces the odd in a concept that will see production next year.
metaTitle: Scion C-HR Concept - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: Scion at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Toyota's youth brand embraces the odd in a concept that will see production next year.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, four-door subcompact crossover/hatchback
Release date: 2016
Estimated price range: Unknown
Competes against: Hyundai Veloster, Kia Soul, Nissan Juke
What's most interesting: Tall ride height
One thing that we know about Toyota's youth-oriented brand, Scion: They aren't afraid to make cars that look a little...unusual.

Case in point is this C-HR Concept (the name stands for "compact" and "high riding"). This concept for a compact hatchback actually started out as a Toyota design study at the 2014 Paris Auto Show, but it's going to come out as a production-model Scion next year. And there's no doubt it fits much better into the wacky Scion stable than the rather more sedate Toyota lineup.

Let's just skip over the awkward claim of Scion officials, at the L.A. show, that the C-HR is for "yuccies," short for young urban creative types. That conjures up unpleasant pictures of bearded, fedora-wearing hipsters. Get beyond the hype, and this is actually a nice blend of crossover and hatchback body shapes without a single boring line to it.

Toyota/Scion said they prioritized agility and stability to make the C-HR a good city runabout. The C-HR features Toyota's New Global Architecture, which incorporates a lower center of gravity, more ride comfort, and a more rigid body. Chief engineer Hiro Koba said he intended the C-HR to be "just as much fun driving in the city during the week" as on the racetrack, where he said he likes to spend his weekends.

Design wise, the C-HR's "cut gem" theme shows in the overall shape as well as the cut-outs in the twenty-one-inch wheels, the side view mirrors, and head- and taillights. No specific on-sale date was given, but expect the production version of the C-HR sometime next year.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/aeeaRrplkE8?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Try to tell an Odyssey family that minivans aren't cool. They'll laugh in your face while they're drinking their chilled beverages from their oh-so-cool cool boxes and vacuuming up the spilled cereal with their built-in vacuum.
There are so many thoughtful features on the 2016 Honda Odyssey that picking five cool things barely scratches the surface.

1. The cool box will fit six eight-ounce cans or four twenty-ounce bottles. It's not a fridge that chills warm beverages but a compartment that uses the Odyssey's air conditioning to keep cold beverages from getting warm.
2. Bluetooth and streaming audio are now standard across all Odyssey trim levels. It's the best way to listen to the tunes stored on your phone.
3. Pair your compatible phone, and you'll be able to receive text messages that will be read to you. And you'll be able to send one of six preprogrammed replies. It lets you stay connected.

4. The third-row Magic Seat. This is for families who need maximum cargo without removing the third row and storing it in the garage. One strap. Pull it down; the seat stows just like that. It's faster than power and creates a flat load floor. Magic.
5. I saved the best for last. I was not kidding about that vacuum. It's built in, and it will pretty much pick up that cereal anywhere it lays.
Pick your own cool things about the Odyssey at automobiles.honda.com/odyssey.

title: Kia Launches Self-Driving-Car Brand
subTitle: If you still doubt that autonomous driving is coming, the Drive Wise initiative should convince you.
promoTeaserSmall: If you still doubt that autonomous driving is coming, the Drive Wise initiative should convince you.
promoTeaser: If you still doubt that autonomous driving is coming, the Drive Wise initiative should convince you.
metaTitle: Kia Launches Self-Driving-Car Brand - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: If you still doubt that autonomous driving is coming, the Drive Wise initiative should convince you.

pageElements.text: Do you believe in the autonomous car? There's one company that clearly does: Kia has just announced it's launching the dedicated Drive Wise sub-brand, with a $2 billion investment, to develop and roll out self-driving cars. That was the announcement at CES in Las Vegas this week, and Kia has obtained permission to road-test autonomous Kia Soul EV cars in Nevada. Next up will be partially autonomous cars, going into production by decade's end, and then the first fully self-driving Kia in the showrooms by 2030.
The Emergency Stop System, or ESS, will pull your car over to the side of the road and stop if it feels you aren't paying close enough attention to the road. Hmm.

This sounds a little...gradual, but Kia's Drive Wise sub-brand has big plans. At CES, the Korean automaker is showing both highway and urban autonomous driving technologies, using radar, camera, GPS, and sensors to let the vehicle operate with driver input or without it. A really fascinating one is the Emergency Stop System, or ESS, which will pull your car over to the side of the road and stop if it feels you aren't paying close enough attention to the road. Hmm. Enhanced lane keeping (Kia calls it Preceding Vehicle Following, or PVF) lets the car calculate its path relative to the vehicle in front, even when road markings aren't visible. There's more, but how about this: Autonomous Valet Parking. Just get out of the car and let it park itself remotely. Human-to-vehicle communication will be improved with gesture recognition and the car's ability to recognize each individual driver by fingerprint or smartwatch, and set up their favorite music, preferred temperature, and instrument panel settings. Kia demonstrated this part at CES with an i-Cockpit simulator display, pointing out how useful it will be to change settings while driving without needing to take your eyes off the road.

These driver assistance systems aren't too far afield from technology being developed and rolled out by many automakers around the world. What's exciting about this is how far it brings automated-vehicle R&D into the mainstream. Kia intends to put this technology in place across its lineup.

See our related story: Kia's New Self-Driving-Car Brand
