title: 5 Ways Your Car Will Do More for You
subTitle: The Consumer Electronics Show showcased tons of tech that will bring self-driving and connected cars into the showroom. Here are our five favorites.
promoTitle: 5 Ways Your Car Will Do More for You
promoTeaserSmall: The Consumer Electronics Show showcased tons of tech that will bring self-driving and connected cars into the showroom. Here are our five favorites.
promoTeaser: The Consumer Electronics Show showcased tons of tech that will bring self-driving and connected cars into the showroom. Here are our five favorites.
keywords: 5 Ways Your Car Will Do More for You
metaTitle: 5 Ways Your Car Will Do More for You - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The Consumer Electronics Show showcased tons of tech that will bring self-driving and connected cars into the showroom. Here are our five favorites.

pageElements.text: How do you feel about self-driving cars? How about using your smartphone to control your car? Much of the new technology is in its infancy, but you’d better get ready: it’s all coming to your local showroom eventually. With it, you’ll be offered more and better safety features, more ability to personalize your time in the car, and more ways to control and manage your driving experience.

At this week’s Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas, the world’s biggest technology showcase was full of announcements of autonomous technology and connectivity features for cars. Here are our five favorites, from five different car companies and their technology partners. Which one will touch your life first? You might be surprised.

image.altText: Kia Soul EV Autonomous Valet Parking

pageElements.text:
1. Kia: Self-Driving Cars that Valet Park Themselves.
Kia has just announced it's launching the Drive Wise sub-brand, with a $2 billion investment, to develop and roll out self-driving cars. Kia has obtained permission to road-test autonomous Kia Soul EV cars in Nevada. Next up will be partially autonomous cars on sale by decade's end, and fully self-driving Kias in the showroom by 2030.

At CES, the Korean automaker is showing both highway and urban autonomous driving tech, using radar, camera, GPS, and sensors to run the car safely with driver input or without it. The Emergency Stop System will pull your car over to the side of the road and stop if it feels you aren't paying close enough attention to the road. There's more, but how about this: Autonomous Valet Parking. Just get out of the car and let it park itself remotely, using your smartphone. No tips required.

2. Ford and Amazon: Talk to Your Car.
Did you get Amazon.com’s Echo home automation device for a gift this year? Millions did. This cylindrical computer’s voice is Alexa, who listens and obeys your commands to play music, adjust lights, and look things up for you at home. Ford announced it’s partnering with Amazon to make it work with your future Ford vehicle. Using it, you’ll be able to start your car remotely and get the heat going, as well as set temperature, seat control, and entertainment features, all using voice controls, before you even get in.

Ford will start giving you greater connectivity options with Sync Connect this spring on the 2017 Escape SUV, and soon afterward to the full lineup. It will let you remotely lock, unlock, and start your vehicle from anywhere, locate your parked car on a map, and look up fuel, battery, and tire pressure information, all from your smartphone. Ford targets getting Sync Connect in more than 10 million Fords worldwide by the end of the decade.

3. BMW: A Simple Swipe of the Hand; No Need to Touch.
You probably make hand gestures occasionally while driving. Now there’s Air Touch from BMW. It will let you wave your hands meaningfully to make things happen—meaning you can use the features of your touchscreen without the distraction of reaching over, finding a control, and touching it. This is an expansion of the Gesture Control feature already available on the BMW 7 Series.

At CES, BMW showed AirTouch on the i Vision Future Interaction, a concept car with a high-resolution twenty-one-inch panoramic display that recognizes hand movement. There's lots more interesting technology on board, including three selectable drive modes to take you from Pure Drive (what we'd call normal), through Assist (active safety features) to Auto Mode. Yes, the self-driving BMW is coming eventually.

4. General Motors: Your First Self-Driving Car May Be a Ride Share
Lyft, a ride-sharing service that often takes a back seat to the more famous Uber, made its own headlines this week as GM announced a long-term partnership. GM will be spending $500 million toward building a network of self-driving cars you can order up with your smartphone. GM chairman Mary Barra announced that the 2017 Chevrolet Bolt, an all-new electric car, will have the smartphone technology on board to make it a centerpiece of this ride-sharing plan. Intriguing! For its part, Lyft will build a network of autonomous cars, while GM will set up national rental hubs where Lyft drivers can pick up non-autonomous vehicles to drive for pay. That’s right, the vision is that eventually you’ll be able to do everything from commuting to earning cash as a driver yourself, all without owning your own car.

5. Volvo: High-Def Video While the Car Drives You
Volvo has an intriguing project with Ericsson known as Intelligent Media Streaming. It will deliver interruption-free, high-definition video that you can watch as the car pilots itself down the road. You’ll even be able to choose from a customized menu of available shows, tailored by length to how much autonomous-driving time the car offers on your commute. "Imagine a highway full of autonomous cars with their occupants sitting back watching their favorite TV shows in high definition," Volvo's Anders Tylman says. We'll leave it to you to decide if that's a dream or a nightmare. And Volvo is planning a major public-road trial of autonomous vehicles in 2017, so it's probably coming sooner than you think.

images.caption: Kia Soul EV autonomous valet parking
General Motors President Dan Ammann (center) with Lyft Inc. co-founders John Zimmer (right) and Logan Green (left)

title: Mitsubishi Focusing on Crossovers
subTitle: By adding a third crossover and EV versions, Mitsubishi makes its way back up the ladder of success.
promoTeaserSmall: By adding a third crossover and EV versions, Mitsubishi makes its way back up the ladder of success.
promoTeaser: By adding a third crossover and EV versions, Mitsubishi makes its way back up the ladder of success.
metaTitle: Mitsubishi Focusing on Crossovers - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: By adding a third crossover and EV versions, Mitsubishi makes its way back up the ladder of success.

pageElements.text: Things looked very rosy for Mitsubishi once...back in 2002, its peak year in the United States. By six years later, the automaker saw sales dive by 80 percent. But Mitusubishi thinks it has the formula to succeed again: focusing on crossovers and committing to electric vehicles.

"We're going to be laser focused on the CUV," said Ken Konieczka, Mitsubishi's North American sales chief, at an event in Detroit this week. That was made clear by fresh new versions of the seven-passenger Outlander and five-passenger Outlander Sport, which rolled out in mid-2015. So far, the approach appears to be working, with the company showing its first operating profit in seven years, and a 23 percent increase in year-over-year sales. This has been a good year for auto sales in general, but still, you can see why Mitsubishi is optimistic about its chances.

In Detroit on Thursday, Mitsubishi showed off the 2017 Outlander PHEV, a battery-electric version of the big crossover that has already been successful in Europe. It's expected to go on sale by late summer here after making its debut at the New York Auto Show in the spring. Reps for the automaker had very few details about the U.S. version—such as price, fuel economy, range—but a quick look at the European model's specs is encouraging. It boasts thirty-two miles of electric-only range, and 541 combined miles between fill-ups. Compare that with the 2016 Chevrolet Volt, which offers a fifty-three-mile all-electric range and 420 miles between fill-ups. What the Outlander loses in its transition to plug-in hybrid status is its third row of seats. The batteries take up that space, and it becomes a five-seater.
The Outlander is getting bigger, longer, and wider in 2019; Outlander Sport will be smaller in 2020, with an EV variant. An all-new crossover will fit in between.

The Outlander PHEV will go on sale in the United States in late summer, at the same time as the 2017 Outlander and Outlander Sport. Since we know, now, that crossovers are going to be so important to Mitsubishi's future, it's good to know that the Outlander is getting bigger, longer, and wider, starting with the 2019 model year, while the Outlander Sport is getting smaller as of the 2020 model year and will have an all-electric version. That leaves room for an all-new crossover in early 2018 that sits between the two. It was previewed in the electric eX Concept shown here, which was introduced at the 2015 Tokyo Auto Show.

images.caption: Mitsubishi eX Concept from 2015 Tokyo Auto Show.

title: 2016 Jeep Renegade: 5 Cool Things
subTitle: Five kinds of fun and practicality, inside and out.
promoTeaserSmall: Five kinds of fun and practicality, inside and out.
promoTeaser: Five kinds of fun and practicality, inside and out.
metaTitle: 2016 Jeep Renegade: 5 Cool Things - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Five kinds of fun and practicality, inside and out.

pageElements.text: 1. That color. Omaha Orange is a historically significant color for Chrysler. The Renegade is based on parent company Fiat's 500X and made in Italy, but its all-American credentials are underlined by its Omega Orange color, a classic for Chrysler that dates back to early 1960s muscle cars. On the 2016 Jeep Renegade Latitude we tested, that orange tint is carried into the interior (see Cool Thing #2). One not-cool thing to add: We love the orange, but those light-cream-colored fabric seats (Sandstorm, they're called) are going to look terrible in a matter of months, no matter how careful you are, and who wants to be careful in a Jeep? Luckily, you can get them in black. Do that.

2. That dashboard. You want a sort of hose-it-out aesthetic in a Jeep, and despite being one of the more citified Jeeps, the dashboard lives up to expectations. Jean compared it to a child's Busy Box play set. Colorful, easy to use, attractive, with a sense of fun.

3. Uconnect infotainment and navigation. You know you have to get navigation on a Jeep, and Chrysler's Uconnect system, a $1,245 option on the Jeep Renegade Latitude, has a 6.5-inch touchscreen, HD radio, and SiriusXM satellite service. The standard touchscreen is five inches.
Beyond the pleasantly intuitive interface that Uconnect represents, you can also appreciate the macho good looks of the system in the Renegade, right down to the "Since 1941" stamped into the frame.

4. Active safety equipment: good backup for the adventurous driver. The Advanced Technology group ($995) gives you lane departure warning, full-speed forward collision warning, and rear park assist. The lane departure warning system does more than blink a warning at you; it gives you a little nudge to the electronic power steering to help keep you in line if you get too far afield in your lane. The Renegade also gets blind spot monitoring, rear cross-path detection, and a rearview camera with dynamic gridlines. If you're a slow convert to these modern aids, don't be; they do very little to impede your fun and a lot to improve your safety on the road.

5. The roof comes off. Chrysler's My Sky power retractable/removable panels cost $1,470, but they are elegant and double the fun of driving this Jeep on a sunny day. The front panel retracts like a normal sunroof, with power open and shut. Want more daylight? You use a cool-looking skeleton key to unlock the panels from the outside, then take them right off and store them in the rear cargo area. Open-air motoring is that easy, and you really feel that you're in a Jeep with the fresh air and sunlight right over your head.

title: Infotainment for the Masses
subTitle: Thanks to Rand McNally, advanced connected-car features without buying the advanced connected car.
promoTeaserSmall: Thanks to Rand McNally, advanced connected-car features without buying the advanced connected car.
promoTeaser: Thanks to Rand McNally, advanced connected-car features without buying the advanced connected car.
metaTitle: Infotainment for the Masses - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Thanks to Rand McNally, advanced connected-car features without buying the advanced connected car.

pageElements.text: What's wrong with the modern in-car infotainment system? The fact that a whole lot of older cars don't have them. Think about how recently the touchscreen started to become ubiquitous. That means there are millions and millions of cars with only a radio on board and none of the high-tech features new-car buyers are flocking to get. At the Chicago Auto Show, we saw one workaround, a versatile aftermarket product that will be available in June.

Rand McNally, the map people, have been honing their infotainment skills with aftermarket products for commercial truck drivers since 2009. Now the company is preparing to roll out OverDryve, an aftermarket tablet specially for the car.
Front collision warning on the cheap is one obvious selling point for this aftermarket product. It works using the camera that's part of the OverDryve tablet.

The basic product is a tablet with a camera, estimated to be priced at $399, which has a magnetic mounting system to let you put it into any car. Once it's in there, you suddenly have access to a whole range of features you might have been relying on your phone—and its expensive data plan—to get. Among them:

Make phone calls, read texts hands-free, record the road ahead with the dash cam or see what's behind you with an optional rearview camera (requires extra equipment installation as shown here and estimated to cost an additional $99). And, of course, you can access navigation that doesn't rely on a data plan.  The OverDryve tablet's main menu has messaging, phone, navigation, cameras, monitoring, and entertainment functions. A microphone icon takes you to the Smart Assistant to respond to calls and texts, launch apps, and do voice control of the functions. Front collision warning on the cheap is one obvious selling point for this aftermarket product. It works using the camera that's part of the OverDryve tablet.

Another optional feature is a tire pressure monitoring system, estimated to cost $169, which includes a transmitter that sits in the glove box and tire gauges that install permanently onto your wheels as shown here. It seems like a lot of trouble (and cash) to find out something you can learn easily with a handheld tire pressure gauge priced under $5, but for those who tow heavy loads or drive commercially, it may be an investment to consider.

How does it work? There's a commercial-grade GPS antenna plus a low-power GPS chip in the device to help ensure that the connection doesn't fail on you. There's also an FM transmitter, an audio auxiliary cord that connects to your car's radio, and a three-watt speaker in the mount. (The average smartphone has a 0.7- or one-watt speaker, according to Rand McNally's spokesman.)
Should you be considering this product for your teen driver, you'll be glad to know it has a Car mode that won't let the user stream movies while the tablet is in place in the car.

OverDryve will come in three sizes: seven, eight, and ten inches, estimated to cost $399, $499, and $599 when they go on sale in June. Best Buy will be the source, with other retailers to follow, Rand McNally's Dave Marsh told us.

That's not cheap, but it's certainly cheaper than a new car, and it's a definite upgrade over a car with only an AM/FM radio. It helps that it's from Rand McNally, the people whose very name conjures up the image of a reference book's gold-trimmed page with a map on it.

title: Chicago Auto Show Wrapup
subTitle: Badass pickups, Nissans on snow treads, and a trip by Amtrak: What I did last week.
promoTeaserSmall: Badass pickups, Nissans on snow treads, and a trip by Amtrak: What I did last week.
promoTeaser: Badass pickups, Nissans on snow treads, and a trip by Amtrak: What I did last week.
metaTitle: Chicago Auto Show Wrapup - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Badass pickups, Nissans on snow treads, and a trip by Amtrak: What I did last week.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The Chicago Auto Show is one of the biggest auto shows in the United States—largest at least by square footage—but it’s not exactly on the front burner for the vast traveling circus of automotive journalists who bounce from Los Angeles to Detroit to New York for the big previews.

Chicago? It’s traditionally a truck show. Unless you’re into reporting on the latest, greatest sport-utilities and full-size earth-mauling pickups, it’s mighty hard to psych yourself up for the equally traditional Chicago Auto Show weather. It is always windy. It is frequently brutally cold, which then makes it brutally cold and windy. And then there is the snow. This year, it was all of that, minus snow, which made it a lot easier to run for your life between cab and restaurant.

The smart people stayed at the Hyatt Regency McCormick attached to the McCormick Place convention center home of the show. That would be me. The fun people (that would be Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean) latched on to a sweet Airbnb a couple of blocks away.

The JKC crew is close enough to drive—a mere 3.5-ish hours away—but an early warning by MLive.com of a coming blizzard with unusually bad lake-effect snow hitting the southernmost crotch of the Lake Michigan shoreline at Gary, Indiana, coupled with -10 to -20 degree temps, sent us to Amtrak. We congratulated Ms. Brown on her brilliant stroke of genius in suggesting that as we heard about pileups that closed I-94 exactly as predicted, both going to and coming back from Chicago.

The train had Wi-Fi and charging outlets in every row. The reclining seats were huge and cozy, with lots of room for luggage overhead or in racks by the car exits. We arrived early to Chicago and only slightly late back home, and an Amtrak app kept us on top of everything.

But enough of the Amtrak.com advertisement.

The show-floor vibe is sleepy at first glance. The place is huge and feels empty, a huge bonus to this claustrophobe. It was a dream to be able to take a slow, careful gander at the most important reveals from Detroit that had been too mobbed to be truly appreciated.

Because I’m a dyed-in-the-wool truck gurrrrl, my joy never stopped running over as one after another manufacturer rolled out crazy big iron. Toyota picked Chicago for the return of the 2017 Tacoma TRD Pro off-road performance pickup. Nissan not only revealed the next full-size Armada SUV, it also threw in a trio of Nissans on snow treads —a Pathfinder, a Murano, and a Rogue. We begged them to bring them to northern Michigan for us to actually drive.

But the real fight is between the top three bestselling vehicles in America. Ford, Chevrolet, and Ram (in that order) duked it out in Chicago for baddest of the badass pickups. I zigzagged from the all-new, 450-horsepower 2017 Ford Raptor to the redesigned 410-horsepower 2017 Dodge 2500 Power Wagon to the new Midnight Special Edition 2016 Chevrolet Silverado 1500 Z71.
Be still my heart. Bring them all to me. But mostly, bring me the 700-horsepower Shelby F-150 Black Ops by Indiana aftermarket company Tuscany. That eclipsed all.

Chevy also brought along some automotive competition in the department of badass reveals: performance variants of the 1LE package in the Camaro SS, available for the first time for both V-6 and V-8 engines. Camaro and Corvette performance tuner Ken Lingenfelter, one of the greatest guys in our business, also tucked in three additions to the Lingenfelter Performance fleet: one supercharged 630-horsepower Gen 6 Camaro, one 600-horsepower Gen 6 Camaro SS, and his personal white Corvette Z06, boosted from 640 hp to 730 hp. He also sells an 800-hp version.
That ought to generate enough heat to keep us all warm until spring. Hope you enjoy our coverage, and don’t forget to weigh in. We love hearing from you!
Love, Jean

title: 2017 Acura MDX
subTitle: Acura teases the redesigned luxury crossover, weeks before its New York Auto Show debut.
promoTeaserSmall: Acura teases the redesigned luxury crossover, weeks before its New York Auto Show debut.
promoTeaser: Acura teases the redesigned luxury crossover, weeks before its New York Auto Show debut.
metaTitle: 2017 Acura MDX - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Acura teases the redesigned luxury crossover, weeks before its New York Auto Show debut.

pageElements.text: Acura has released this teaser image of the upcoming all-new 2017 MDX luxury crossover, scheduled to make its official debut on March 23 at the New York Auto Show. The 2017 model, Acura says, will upgrade the current powertrain, which is a 3.5-liter V-6 teamed with a nine-speed automatic transmission. There will also be "substantial" appearance changes. The front end, as the image shows, is already looking much more clean than that of the outgoing model.
We can see why Honda's luxury division is motivated to update the MDX; they sell 50,000-plus MDX crossovers every year.

The MDX dates back to the 2001 model year. In its debut year, it won the Best Performer prize from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety for bumper safety and was named North American Truck of the Year. It's the top-selling full-size luxury sport-utility vehicle of all time and has inspired a legion of competitors—everyone from Audi to Volvo has a three-row SUV or crossover to stack against it these days—but its strongest competition comes from the Lexus RX, which has much less conservative styling. (2016 Acura MDX pictured.)

The Acura MDX may be popular, but nobody can accuse it of being edgy in its design, at least to date. Its Jewel Eye lighting in front is attractive in a low-key way, but it has been an introverted kind of fashionability. The Acura Precision Concept shown at the Detroit auto show in January was justly praised for its interesting pointy-nose treatment. It will be interesting to see how far the Honda luxury division will go with its cash cow when we see it at the New York Auto Show in a few weeks.

title: 2013 Ford Edge
subTitle: Its looks aren’t edgy, but it edges closer to stylishness than the average boxy people carrier.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Ford Edge
promoTeaser: 2013 Ford Edge
metaTitle: 2013 Ford Edge
metaDescription: 2013 ford edge buyer's guide

pageElements.text: Ford’s Edge is all about versatility. It’s about moving beyond the carpool mindset and going for something more appealing to drive. Its looks are on the curvy side, distancing it from the boxy minivan aesthetic, yet it still has the kind of interior space a cargo- and kid-carrying family will appreciate. The Edge can be fitted with a turbocharged four-cylinder or one of two V6 choices. With the four, fuel economy is 21 mpg in the city and an impressive 30 mpg on the highway, while the V6s offer 19 mpg in town and 26 or 27 mpg on the highway. All-wheel drive is an option for all models; it cuts fuel economy by about 2 mpg.

The Edge offers well-tuned and responsive steering, along with some of the latest in safety technology: roll stability control, side air curtains for the first and second rows of seats, and blind-spot mirrors. A Blind Spot Information System is optional. Ford’s Sync multimedia system and MyFord Touch touchscreen interface are both available on every Edge except for the base model, but prepare for a learning curve. The top-end Edge, the Sport, has the biggest V6 (305 horsepower) and lots of upscale goodies, including paddle shifters for the six-speed automatic transmission, charcoal leather-trimmed seats with metallic silver inserts, a Sony audio system with HD radio, six-way heated power seats, 22-inch polished aluminum wheels with black spokes, and chrome oval dual exhaust. It also comes with a $10,000 higher price than the $27,525 of the base Edge, starting at $37,110.

title: 2013 Ford Explorer
subTitle: All-purpose SUV has crossed over into crossover territory, and the crowds love it more than ever.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Ford Explorer
promoTeaser: 2013 Ford Explorer
metaTitle: 2013 Ford Explorer Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Ford Explorer Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Ford Explorer is a huge seller and a familiar sight on the roads of America. Long a traditional rear-wheel-drive SUV, the Explorer was completely remade for 2011 into a front-wheel-drive/all-wheel-drive crossover. It even comes with the option of a four-cylinder engine. That hasn’t changed its reputation as a go-anywhere utility vehicle, though. Teamed with all-wheel drive on V-6-powered models is Ford’s optional Terrain Management. This system lets you dial in the vehicle’s response to the surfaces on which you’re traveling, using pictograms for grass/gravel/snow, sand, mud/ruts, or normal. There’s also Hill Descent Control, which takes over the braking duties when you go downhill, so you can concentrate on steering. Other helpful features include adaptive cruise control, a blind-spot warning system, and parking assist. The Explorer Sport model gives you both more power and more style, with 350 horsepower from a twin-turbo V-6 engine, a set of twenty-inch wheels, and contrast stitching on the seats. As for fuel economy, you can get 28 mpg on the highway, but only if you forgo all-wheel drive and get the four-cylinder engine. With the V-6 and AWD, you’ll get 23 mpg on the highway, and the Explorer Sport tops out at 22 mpg highway. It’s not the most exciting product on the market, either to drive or to look at—but for those who want to haul stuff, carry up to seven people, and feel more like a rugged adventurer than a boring commuter, the Explorer is a popular choice.

Fun-O-Meter:
6.5

Competitors:
1. Honda Pilot
2. Toyota Highlander
3. Jeep Grand Cherokee
4. Chevrolet Traverse

Cool Tech Items:
1. Optional Terrain Management System that lets you dial in terrain pictograms for sand, mud/ruts, grass/gravel/snow, or normal; it then adjusts torque and throttle settings.
2. Curve Control slows the vehicle by up to 10 mph if a curve is being taken too fast.
3. Inflatable rear seatbelts (optional).

Looks:
1. Power folding third-row seat folds flat into floor (optional).
2. Two-tone leather and contrasting stitching on the seats in Explorer Sport.

New for 2013:
1. Lane-keeping assist.
2. Heated steering wheel.
3. Power tilting/telescoping steering wheel.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: What parent hasn't ordered a teen driver to "call me when you get there"?
Well, that command may be a thing of the past, thanks to a futuristic Ford mobile app.
The Dearborn automaker and its research partners are working on an app that can provide "selected personal contacts with an automatic location update during [a] driver's travels."
The mobile app would monitor a vehicle's location and speed. It would automatically notify "the driver's family following a safe arrival after a road trip," said Ford in a statement on February 16.

The app also would help working women. Ford said it can determine if a driver is running late for a meeting and then send an e-mail or text message notification to other attendees without any input from the driver.
No word yet on any production plans for such an app or what it would cost.
The app is part of Ford's OpenXC research project, a hardware and software platform developed by Ford Research and Innovation and New York City-based Bug Labs.

Ford said developers working with OpenXC will be able to create apps "across a wide spectrum of categories, from those dealing with personal information and entertainment to those who are contributing to a better world - such as directly addressing congestion, and the needs of road safety, healthcare and education."
The only question is whether consumers will think the technology is too intrusive.

title: 2013 Toyota 4Runner
subTitle: Still aimed at the off-road crowd, the 4Runner ain’t so bad for city slickers, either.
promoTeaserSmall: Still aimed at the off-road crowd, the 4Runner ain’t so bad for city slickers, either.
promoTeaser: Still aimed at the off-road crowd, the 4Runner ain’t so bad for city slickers, either.
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota 4Runner - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Toyota 4Runner here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Toyota’s 4Runner SUV has been with us for roughly three decades, and during that time, Toyota has done a reasonable job keeping it true to the tenets of the basic original. Based on Toyota’s “compact” Tacoma pickup, the 4Runner is still an excellent off-roader. However, with the whimsically styled and even more off-road-inclined FJ Cruiser also in the 2013 lineup, Toyota has taken the 4Runner’s trim levels considerably upmarket. Particularly in the fancy Limited grade, with standard leather seating, push-button start, navigation, and a slew of options including a fifteen-speaker sound system, the 4Runner is downright posh. Powering the 4Runner is a grunty, if a tad raucous, 270-horsepower 4.0-liter V-6 paired with a five-speed automatic—not the most sophisticated powerplant in the Toyota lineup but entirely capable. (If you’re looking for a smooth operator, check out the Highlander crossover.) Fuel economy is so-so, but to its credit, an eco-driving feedback system allows the driver to see just how much gas the vehicle is swilling at any given time. Off-roading remains a specialty for the 4Runner; particularly in Trail grade, no mid-size SUVs other than the Jeep Grand Cherokee and the aforementioned FJ Cruiser can keep up with the 4Runner once the pavement ends. Our favorite 4Runner feature, however (standard on all trim levels, thankfully), is the stereo, with its outward-facing speakers in the back for tailgate parties.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Nissan Pathfinder
2. Jeep Grand Cherokee
3. Dodge Durango

Cool Tech Items:
1. Available Entune app suite with Bing, Pandora, and more.
2. Stereo with party mode and rear-facing speakers for tailgating.
3. Corner-carving X-REAS suspension system on Limited model.

Looks:
1. High ground clearance, hood scoop, bumper guards, and water-resistant upholstery on Trail grade.
2. Chrome grille and bumper molding on SR5 and Limited.
3. Twenty-inch wheels and standard leather interior on Limited grade.

New for 2013:
1. Switch-style transfer case operation.
2. Advanced connectivity and audio systems.

title: 2013 Infiniti EX
subTitle: The 2013 Infiniti EX is getting a little long in the tooth, but still manages to convey a sense of high style.
promoTeaserSmall: The 2013 Infiniti EX is getting a little long in the tooth, but still manages to convey a sense of high style.
promoTeaser: The 2013 Infiniti EX is getting a little long in the tooth, but still manages to convey a sense of high style.
metaTitle: 2013 Infiniti EX - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Infiniti EX here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Two major changes are on tap for the 2013 Infiniti EX – a 325-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 engine that replaces the previous 3.5-liter V-6 and some new nomenclature. Gone is the EX35 model and in its place is the EX37. Infiniti says the rear-wheel-drive model returns 17 mpg in city driving and 25 mpg on the highway. The EX37 is getting a little long in the tooth and is due for a major revision. Despite that, the midsize luxury crossover that seats five still manages to convey a sense of high style. The crossover, which also can be ordered in all-wheel-drive configuration, earns kudos for its acceleration and handling. Front-seat passengers are coddled, but back-seat passengers may feel like second-class citizens. It’s just plain cramped back there, plus there is limited cargo room in the rear. Standard features are plentiful and include leather-trimmed seats, a smart key with push-button start, and eight-spoke eighteen-inch aluminum-alloy wheels. But it’s a mystery why upscale Infiniti charges extra for an optional driver’s seat headrest coat hanger and the better audio systems. There’s lots of useful technology as well, but be prepared to pay extra for it. Those options include a blind spot warning system, lane departure prevention system, intelligent cruise control, and intelligent brake assist with forward collision warning. The 2013 EX starts at $37,300, including an $950 destination charge, making it $2,645 cheaper than a base 2013 BMW X3. But keep in mind that the optional premium package on the EX37 adds another $3,050 to the bottom line, while the tech package costs $2,750.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. BMW X3
2. Acura RDX
3. Mercedes-Benz GLK-Class

Cool Tech:
1. Optional Around View monitor uses four small cameras located front, side, and rear to give the driver a “top-down view” of the outside of the vehicle and help reduce blind spots when parking.

New for 2013:
1. EX37 model replaces previous EX35 model.
2. 325-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 replaces previous 3.5-liter V-6.

title: 2013 Infiniti G
subTitle: Infiniti simplifies and strips down the 2013 Infiniti G lineup, discontinuing the gateway-to-the-brand G25 sedan.
promoTeaserSmall: Infiniti simplifies and strips down the 2013 Infiniti G lineup, discontinuing the gateway-to-the-brand G25 sedan.
promoTeaser: Infiniti simplifies and strips down the 2013 Infiniti G lineup, discontinuing the gateway-to-the-brand G25 sedan.
metaTitle: 2013 Infiniti G Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Infiniti G here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Infiniti G has been praised as one of the most driver-focused vehicles in the entry-luxury segment, with an entertaining rear-wheel-drive chassis and responsive engines. The lineup includes sedan, coupe, and convertible models. In a somewhat puzzling move, Infiniti has simplified and stripped down the 2013 Infiniti G lineup, discontinuing the base G25 sedan, G37 Sport Appearance Edition, and G37 Limited Edition, leaving the upscale Nissan brand without a true competitor to the Lexus IS 250. The Infiniti G37 Coupe base model is no longer available. There are now only three models in the G sedan lineup: the G37 Sedan Journey, G37 Sedan Sport 6MT, and G37x Sedan AWD.  Prices range from $37,795, including an $895 destination charge, for the base Sedan Journey to $42,395 for the Sedan Sport 6MT. All Gs now get a standard 328-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 engine mated to either a seven-speed automatic transmission or a six-speed manual transmission. The G convertible is our least favorite of the body styles because the retractable hard top can squeak and creak on all but the smoothest roads. The G gets high marks for good handling, user-friendly controls, and attractive cabin materials. The G37 still ranks as one of the most fun-to-drive cars in its class, but the cramped rear seat in the coupe and convertible models is best left to small kids.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Audi A4
2. BMW 3 Series
3. Lexus IS
4. Mercedes-Benz C-Class

New for 2013:
1. Simplified sedan lineup.
2. G37 coupe base model no longer available.
3. Revised stone interior color with graphite components on coupe.
4. Standard Silk Obi aluminum interior trim replaces Shodo aluminum trim.

title: 2013 Mazda 3
subTitle: The 2013 Mazda 3 is sporty, but polarizing.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mazda 3
promoTeaser: 2013 Mazda 3
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda 3 Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda 3 here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Mazda 3 is one of our favorite compact cars, with sporty handling and a wider availability of the efficient Skyactiv drivetrain technology on tap for the new model year. But despite a recent makeover that toned down the Mazda 3’s goofy grille, the styling can be polarizing. On the plus side, some models – the Mazda 3 comes in sedan or hatchback form– get up to 40 mpg on the highway. If you want to save at the pump, check out the 155-horsepower Skyactiv-G 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine. But you’re going to find a bit of a trade-off since the Mazda 3 is relatively expensive. While the base 2013 Mazda 3 starts at just under $16,000, including a $795 destination charge, the top-of-the-line model is priced at $23,695, including shipping. The Mazda 3 is meant for people who don’t think of their car as an appliance and want a sportier look and feel. The compact Mazda doesn’t disappoint in this area, offering five- or six-speed manual transmissions, in addition to a five- or six-speed automatic transmission. The handling is more performance-oriented than you usually find in this class. The interior has good quality materials and there are upscale options, such as a blind spot monitoring system, something that you usually see on luxury cars.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Ford Focus
2. Honda Civic
3. Hyundai Elantra
4. Nissan Versa
5. Toyota Corolla

Cool Tech:
1. Blind spot monitoring system is optional and usually found on more expensive vehicles.

New for 2013:
1. Air conditioning is now standard.
2. Skyactiv 2.0-liter four-cylinder now comes on the i Sport sedan in addition to two other Mazda 3s.
3. USB port and a driver-information system.

title: 2013 Aston Martin Rapide
subTitle: Four doors of decadent fantasy driving in drop-dead gorgeous couture.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Aston Martin Rapide
promoTeaser: 2013 Aston Martin Rapide
metaTitle: 2013 Aston Martin Rapide Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Aston Martin Rapide Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Rapide is the only Aston Martin in which double dates are possible. Two couples can go out to dinner in chic style. Of course, the couple in the backseat should be of the petite variety, because the legroom in the Rapide is minimal. But what’s on the inside of the cabin is gorgeous – embodied in the sculptural shape of the Rapide’s gauges. The Rapide Luxe adds even more stylish pizzazz with a six-piece luggage set, ventilated seats, glass switchgear, and a rear entertainment system. The Rapide is a leaner interpretation of a four-door super car, especially when pitted against the brawny Porsche Panamera. It’s a four-seater that has retained its elegance. DB9 DNA is carried over in the 6.0-liter V-12 engine that produces 470 horsepower and climbs from 0 to 60 mph in 5 seconds. It also has a top speed of 183 mph. In this car, your petite friends can ride in style, while you can enjoy being seen behind the wheel of an Aston Martin.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Porsche Panamera Turbo S
2. Ferrari FF

Cool Tech items:
1. Dual-screen rear entertainment system in the Luxury model has two 6.5-inch LCD screens.
2. Ventilated front and rear seats.
3. Standard Bang & Olufsen sound system.

Looks
1. The Rapide Luxe has glass switchgears and a six-piece luggage set available in a variety of colors.
2. The gauges, like much of the Rapide's cabin, are works of art.
3. The logo can be embroidered onto the headrest to match the color of the steering wheel and interior.

title: 2013 Audi A3
subTitle: All the class of Audi in an unlikely wrapping
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Audi A3
promoTeaser: 2013 Audi A3
metaTitle: 2013 Audi A3 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi A3 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: A compact wagon was a novel idea when the Audi A3 came on the market, but since then the A3 has found a home with buyers. The hatchback means there is plenty of room in the trunk, but you won’t feel cramped sitting in the back. The A3 has an available all-wheel-drive system that is unique to its class, and the choice of a turbo-diesel engine means that it can make up to 42 mpg on the highway. The diesel engine is only available in a six-speed automatic, but a six-speed manual is available when you give up the efficiency of the diesel for a standard engine. The interior is awash in typical Audi luxury, with leather trim and seating surfaces, as well as Audi’s navigation and Bose sound system. Though the A3 has a history as the best choice for a small wagon, there are more options these days and it may be worth checking out some of the competition. The A3’s design could use an update to keep up with the pack, but Audi’s name and engineering are usually a good recommendation, and this car is not likely to disappoint.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competition:
1. Lexus CT200h
2. Volkswagen Golf

Cool Tech:
1. Diesel engine earns more than 40 mpg on the highway.
2. Bose sound system with auxiliary jack, available Bluetooth connectivity.
3. Stand-out Audi all-wheel drive.

Look:
1. Luxurious, leather-heavy interior.
2. Available in bright colors including Brilliant Red and Scuba Blue Metallic, three available seat colors.

title: 2013 Audi A7
subTitle: Really fast, really good-looking, and it has a hatchback!
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Audi A7
promoTeaser: 2013 Audi A7
metaTitle: 2013 Audi A7 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Audi A7 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Audi’s A7 may be the most unconventional car in its lineup, offering a breath of fresh air from the rest of Audi’s bold-but-similar sedans. The A7 stands out from the crowd because it pairs excessive speed with an unexpected hatchback. No need to worry that Audi has somehow created a dowdy car – the hatchback fits with the A7’s sleek lines and does nothing to slow this car down. The 2013 model will have a top speed electronically limited at 130 mph, while a brand new S7 model is limited to 155 mph. That’s fast enough to make you consider running from those flashing red lights.  Audi didn’t skimp on the interior, either. The 2013 A7 will seat five for the first time with a new middle seat in the second row. Audi’s trademark Google Earth map technology is available, as is an excruciatingly pricey Bang & Olufsen stereo. The A7 will save some fuel with new technology that turns the engine off while the car stands at a stop, and seamlessly back on again when you start rolling. With everything the A7 offers it’s hard to imagine wanting anything else. Except maybe a half-off coupon.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. BMW 5-series GT
2. Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class
3. Porsche Panamera

Cool Tech:
1. Despite huge power, gets almost 30 mpg highway.
2. Start/stop fuel-saving engine technology.
3. Available Audi MMI Google interface and mobile hotspot.

Looks:
1. Unexpected, but attractive hatchback.
2. S7 has leather seats and steering wheel.
3. Small rear spoiler for increased stability.

New for 2013:
1. Fifth seat in A7.
2. All-new S7 model.

title: Interstates Are for Wimps!
promoTeaserSmall: JKC's associate editor makes the most of the fleeting days of youth.
promoTeaser: JKC's associate editor makes the most of the fleeting days of youth.
metaTitle: Interstates Are for Wimps! - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Interstates Are for Wimps! A trip on the Pacific Coast Highway in a 2003 Nissan Murano by JKC associate editor Annie White.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Staying put doesn’t come naturally to me. I lived in one place for most of my young life, and all I ever thought about was getting out. The summer after my freshman year of college, I never stayed in the same place for more than six days in a row. By the spring of my senior year, I had lived in three cities in the space of nine months and was growing restless again.

So, with one month to go to graduation I stuck a map of the United States on the wall above my bed and, in the cliché of old, started sticking thumbtacks in it. One in each “must-see” national park. One in Nashville, one in New Orleans, one in San Francisco, one in Portland, one in DC. Then I took a pencil and mapped the route. No interstates, interstates are for wimps and long haul truck drivers. No hotels, hotels are for rich people and parents with small children.

If you’ve never mapped a circuit around the United States that uses only state highways and stops only at campgrounds, I can tell you that it is a long, long road. If you’ve never tried to plan a several-month-long vacation with the budget of a college student who has recently spilled her savings across Western Europe, I can tell you that it is almost impossible. So I rethought. I left the pins in Portland, San Francisco, and Yosemite. I drew a big, thick line down the Pacific Coast Highway, that road of legend. As far west as you can go without falling into the ocean. It’s not the fastest way from Portland to San Francisco, but I felt sure that it was the only way worth going.
Oregon Coast, fog and infinity

Two months after graduation, as the second week of August dawned and a truly fantastic breakfast from the Pelican Brewery in Pacific City, Oregon, settled in my stomach, my cousin Ellen and I took to the road. We’d flown in to Oregon the week before and spent several days playing sand volleyball and climbing the dunes with a sampling of family members, one of whom enabled our flight south by lending us a 2003 Nissan Murano, referred to as Orange Car by those who love it.
 
In Oregon, Highway 101 alternates between flat, straight sections of road that run through tourist towns and curving, climbing portions that hug the cliffs and weave through forests. Sometimes I would whip around a corner (always driving a little too fast because why not?) and suddenly realize we were on the edge of land, nothing between us and the sea.

When the sky is clear, this is exhilarating. To your left, mossy cliffs. To your right, blue. Blue forever, as far as you can see, and you feel like if you let go of the wheel you would fly off and explode in a blaze of glory. And you’re almost tempted to, except you know it’s just a feeling and what would really happen is you would tumble off the road and smash into the rocks below, nothing glorious about it.

When the sky is not clear, when the fog is pressing in and you can’t see more than fifty feet in front of you, it’s a litmus test. The space behind the fog could be infinity or oblivion. Heaven and hell and god and death and everything could be back there. Or it could just be fog and nothing else.
Among the Giants

Our planning for this Great Adventure had essentially amounted to saying “It’ll be fine, right?” and marching inexorably forward as if we actually knew what we were doing. We had friends and relations who we thought would be able to put us up, we had a car and (we were fairly certain) enough money to keep it fueled up. We had a tent and a camp stove; we had a really unnecessary amount of beer and bacon. I often travel this way, and it has always worked for me. I find it less stressful – if you don’t have plans you can’t worry about messing them up. Of course this all falls apart if the universe fails to provide you with something essential, like a place to sleep or transportation. But then, what is the ground for? What are your feet for?

That first day we drove to Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park in Northern California. A few months before, I had camped in the same park for two nights and hiked fourteen miles deep into the woods almost without seeing another soul. This time we didn’t have time for a hike, but after snagging the last campsite in the park and setting up camp in the pitch dark we sat below the starriest sky I’ve ever seen with a cold beer and a brat each. When I lived in Boston, I was excited when a move across town and further from the city lights brought exactly five stars into view. In the Redwoods, I was pretty sure that that whole thing in the bible about god numbering the stars was straight bullshit.
Sunshine

The next morning, I took the first shift again and was soon forced into a reluctant detour from Highway 101. We had to cross the mountains so that we would be directly north of Yosemite. We found ourselves weaving through the mountains for four hours, nervously checking the fuel gauge against the distance to the next town. Around lunchtime, I pulled to the side of the road in a sparkling valley with a low river running through it. This is the great thing about the West Coast – you go there expecting mountains and forests and river valleys that glisten in the late afternoon sunlight and the place delivers.

We waded in the river and reveled in the fresh mountain air. At that moment, it was hard to imagine ever wanting to be anywhere else. In fact, the only thing that got me driving again was knowing I would be soon be speeding back down the mountain on a wickedly twisty road with no one else around.

Four days later, after 25 (or so) miles hiked, three swims in mountain streams, one hitchhiking trip (the first of my life; we taught an Ecuadorian couple how to pronounce “squirrel”) two gas fill-ups at more than $5 per gallon, and at least twelve moments in which I was astonished that places like that even exist, we headed north again by way of San Francisco.

Driving back across the mountains further south, we travelled a section of road that rested hundreds of feet above a huge reservoir, its level visibly depleted by drought. It seemed completely plausible that we would miss one of the hairpin turns, and as we swept into the valley, with Orange Car’s steering responding almost as quickly as I wanted it to, and I kept thinking: “I am going to die on this road.” Call me crazy, but part of me loves moments like that, moments when I’m almost out of my depth. When I’m not really sure if I can hack it. But I always do, because there’s no other choice.
The best kind of driving is the kind that pushes the limits. Find the boundary between sane and not, then ride it as hard as you can.
Back to Portland

The drive back to Portland took at least twice as long as we wanted it to. This was mainly due to the fact that Highway 1 driving north from San Francisco was designed either by a madman or someone who thought that cars would never go faster than thirty miles an hour, or maybe both. It would be the drive of a lifetime if you had a car that was designed for its ability to negotiate demanding roads and not for its ability to hold three car seats. In Orange Car, we had to balance our desire to survive the trip with my desire to drive really fast (Ellen is much more sensible). We ended up driving carefully, but also slowly. After a week of driving in perfect, beautiful countryside we almost wished there were just a straight shot home. I say almost, because the drive was still nothing short of wonderful.

By the time we made it to our campsite, we were tired and not particularly interested in cooking (I don’t want to tell you how many Cheetos we ate on that trip, but it was enough that neither of us was hungry for dinner). And even though the two and a half hours I spent that night trying to build a fire ended in ashes and broken dreams, I was still content.

I had spent a week hanging out with family and friends, and almost nothing had gone wrong. The weather was beautiful; we didn’t get hurt or sick. The people we met lent us maps and wisdom and mattresses and fed us delicious food. We swam in mountain streams. We didn’t get eaten by bears.
By my estimation, our luck only deserted us once, in that last night at that last campsite with the fire that refused to become a fire.

People love travel for different reasons. Some people don’t love it at all. I’ve always felt the call to wander, and I’m rarely disappointed by what happens when I step out my front door. The world is an endlessly fascinating place, and driving across part of it is as good a way to see it as I can come up with. The fact that I got to wring a car out on the mountain roads is just a bonus.
