title: 2013 Nissan Maxima
subTitle: 2013 Nissan Maxima
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan Maxima
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan Maxima
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Maxima Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Maxima here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Maxima absolutely gets the big stuff right. It has tons of power, a comfortable ride, bold exterior styling and an upscale interior. But despite being touted as a sport sedan by the Japanese automaker, its front-wheel-drive layout and continuously variable transmission make it fall short of its lofty goal. Dare we call it a family-friendly sedan without insulting Nissan designers? The five-passenger sedan serves as Nissan’s flagship, but it suffers from a smallish cabin. It is again offered in two models, 3.5 S and 3.5 SV, each powered by a standard 290-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 engine. It returns decent fuel economy at 19 mpg in city driving and 26 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. One downside: the Maxima requires premium gasoline and that can raise your fuel budget compared to other models that get roughly the same ratings. The ride in the Maxima is well damped and comfortable with fairly limited body roll. The sloping roofline in the rear limits headroom for backseat passengers and the high beltline may make smaller passengers feel slightly claustrophobic. The biggest problem with the Maxima, though, may come from the Nissan stable. The less-expensive Nissan Altima sedan received a major makeover for the 2013 model year, which may steer some buyers away from Maxima once they step into a Nissan showroom.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford Taurus
2. Acura TL
3. Chrysler 300
4. Volvo S60

New for 2013:
1. New SV Value Package featuring nine-speaker Bose audio system, SiriusXM satellite radio, heated front seats, heated steering wheel, and heated outside mirrors.
2. Sport Package has been revised to add Monitor Package content, including seven-inch color monitor, USB connectivity, iPod net in center console, climate-controlled driver’s seat, and Dark Hyper Silver finished nineteen-inch aluminum-alloy wheels.
3. Pearl White is new exterior color.

title: 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet
subTitle: The 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet is one controversial crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet
promoTeaser: 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet
metaTitle: 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet is the convertible version of the Nissan Murano crossver. It’s hard to find a more polarizing ride. Some are intrigued by its droptop fair-weather potential, others gripe that it looks bloated and ridiculous. The Murano CrossCabriolet is plagued by convertible issues like a body that shakes when it goes over bumps since it doesn’t have a solid roof to boost rigidity. It also offers minimal cargo space and has poor rear and side visibility. The unusual convertible gets a power cloth top roof, all-wheel drive and comes in just one model. It is equipped with a 265-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6 engine linked to a continuously variable transmission. In a rare twist on a convertible, the CrossCabriolet can tow up to 3,500 pounds. It can be dressed up with optional quilted leather-trimmed seating and comes with twenty-inch five-spoke titanium finish aluminum-alloy wheels. Standard safety features are plentiful and include dual pop-up roll bars for rear passengers. Nissan dropped the price of the CrossCabriolet for the 2012 model year and has not yet announced pricing on the 2013 model. Be prepared to pay more than you would for a conventional Nissan Murano. You should also be prepared to stand out in a crowd in this rare crossover, especially if you opt for Caribbean, a retro-looking aqua exterior color.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Jeep Wrangler
2. Land Rover Range Rover Evoque
3. Lexus IS C

New for 2013:
1. Nissan has not announced changes or pricing to 2013 CrossCabriolet.

title: 2013 BMW X3
subTitle: Downsizing the standard engine results in fuel savings without a loss of performance
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 BMW X3
promoTeaser: 2013 BMW X3
metaTitle: 2013 BMW X3 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows cars
metaDescription: 2013 BMW X3 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The X3 can get expensive in a hurry, but it can get everywhere else in a hurry, too. That remains true even though a 2.0-liter four-cylinder replaced the six-cylinder that was initially offered in the X3 28i. This turbocharged four is very energetic and produces the same 240 horsepower as the old engine, but it burns fuel more frugally. That ought to put a smile on the face of anyone who takes satisfaction in doing more with less. Meanwhile, the X3 35i uses a 3.0-liter six-cylinder, and the output is 300 horsepower. An eight-speed automatic is the only transmission in the X3 range. Driving Dynamics Control allows you to select either of two sport modes, which regulate variability in steering effort, transmission shift points, and the vigilance of the stability control system, but the result is a jumpy, nervous vehicle that shifts gears frenetically. The normal mode is fine. A good thing about DDC, though, is the Eco Pro mode that monitors all onboard mechanical systems and electrical functions for efficiency. It even relays tactful suggestions about your lead-footed style of driving, if this is warranted. Quicker down the road, plusher inside, and better-riding than ever, the X3 has already made big steps forward. Now, add those further refinements.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi Q5
2. Cadillac SRX
3. Infiniti FX

Cool Tech:
1. Automatic stop/start, a standard feature adopted as a fuel-saving strategy, completely shuts off the engine while you sit at intersections, then restarts it when you release the brake.
2. Lane departure warning is a new option.
3. Direct injection helps the standard turbocharged four-cylinder engine to match the old six-cylinder’s output.

Looks
1. Nineteen-inch wheels are available on the X3 xDrive28i with the M Sport package.
2. The X3 xDrive28i receives eighteen-inch wheels and chrome tailpipes as standard equipment.
3. Panoramic moonroof is available with X3 xDrive35i.

New for 2013
1. Power tailgate is standard.
2. Eco Pro overall vehicle-efficiency mode is part of standard Dynamic Driving Control system.
3. Driver Assistance package (including lane-departure warning) is optional.

title: 2013 Buick Regal
subTitle: This is a more interesting car than you might think. Whether you’re looking for fuel economy or driving excitement, there’s a Regal worth looking at.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Buick Regal
promoTeaser: 2013 Buick Regal
metaTitle: 2013 Buick Regal Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Buick Regal Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Consider for a moment the Buick Regal. You may see this mid-size sedan as serviceable but uninteresting. But what about the Turbo, which gives you 270 horsepower worth of driving interest? Then there’s the eAssist mild hybrid model, which gives you 36 mpg on the highway thanks to its lithium-ion battery and electric motor that work together to power regenerative braking and save fuel. Did we mention that Buick’s IntelliLink is standard on all models? That system hooks up your smartphone and other mobile devices, lets you customize programming, and allows streaming audio from your phone via Pandora or other Internet services. Last but not least, consider that the Regal is based on the European Opel Insignia, and you might find yourself looking at this Buick in a different light.  Traction control, foglamps, leather-trimmed seating, heated front seats, ice blue ambient lighting, and a seven-inch touchscreen are all standard on every model. The GS turbo model has special tuning, including a modified front suspension, but no all-wheel-drive option. GS models have an interactive drive control system with standard, sport, tour, and enthusiast-oriented GS settings; it’s optional on the turbo. A set of twenty-inch polished alloy wheels is optional on GS models, too. All of that helps explain why the Regal is the core of Buick's product line.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Acura TSX
2. Audi A4
3. Lincoln MKZ
4. Volkswagen CC

Cool Tech:
1. eAssist with the standard 2.4-liter four.

New for 2013:
1. Buick IntelliLink now standard on all models.
2. Heated steering wheel on turbos except GS.

title: 2013 Kia Forte/Forte Koup
subTitle: The 2013 Kia Forte/Forte Koup are still a solid value in the small-car segment, despite a modest price hike.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Kia Forte/Forte Koup
promoTeaser: 2013 Kia Forte/Forte Koup
metaTitle: 2013 Kia Forte/Forte Koup Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Kia Forte/Forte Koup here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The 2013 Kia Forte and Forte Koup are the Korean automaker’s entry-level compact offerings that take their name from the French word “forte,” meaning “a strong point.” The entry-level Kias live up to their name and have a solid reputation built on crisp, clean styling and a choice of four-cylinder engines. The carryover Forte is available as a sedan, hatchback, and coupe, which Kia calls the Koup. The Forte LX and EX models are equipped with a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine that produces 156 horsepower. The uplevel Forte SX gets a 173-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine. The EPA says the smaller engine with a six-speed automatic transmission returns 26 mpg in city driving and 36 mpg on the highway. The EX model with the 2.0-liter engine can be outfitted with an optional Eco Package that includes a “smart” alternator and low-rolling-resistance silica tires that give the fuel economy a little boost. Competition is heating up in the small-car segment, with the Hyundai Elantra and Ford Focus stealing some of the limelight away from the Forte. Kia is still a good value in the segment, despite the fact that the Forte gets a modest price increase of around $225 for the new model year. Expect to pay $16,175, including a $775 destination charge for the 2013 Forte sedan, $18,175 for the Forte Koup, and $19,075 for the Forte hatchback. But that’s still under the $20,000 mark, a critically important psychological barrier for many buyers.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Honda Civic
2. Hyundai Elantra
3. Ford Focus
4. Toyota Corolla
5. Mazda 3

Cool Tech:
1. Eco Package on the Forte EX model adds a ‘smart’ alternator and low-rolling-resistance silica tires for a fuel-economy boost.

New for 2013:
1. Minor styling enhancement on Forte and Forte hatchback.
2. New design for sixteen-inch alloy wheels.
3. New LED daytime running lights.
4. Power-folding exterior mirrors are standard on EX and SX models.

title: 2013 Chrysler 200
subTitle: The new 200 begins to eclipse the Sebring’s flawed past and makes comfort and elegance affordable for all
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Chrysler 200
promoTeaser: 2013 Chrysler 200
metaTitle: 2013 Chrysler 200 Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Chrysler 200 Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: You may love the sleek styling and cushy interiors of the upscale sedans on the market, but some of them are a little pricey. Luckily for you, the 200 offers all the classy comforts of those other high-end vehicles, but at a more reasonable price: the car’s base model retails for less than $19,000. A vast improvement over the late Chrysler Sebring, the 200 offers you a fuel economy of up to 31 mpg highway, as well as high-quality “soft touch” interiors. For those of you in frostier climes, you may want to consider either the Limited or 200S models: both feature remote start and heated front seats, which are perfect for keeping warm on those long morning commutes when thermal underwear just isn’t enough. There are two engine choices: the 2.4-liter four-cylinder or Chrysler’s new 3.6-liter Pentastar V-6, which only comes with the Limited sedan. You also have the choice of a four- or six-speed transmission, but the latter is only available as a standard feature on the Touring and Limited editions. But whereas the sedan has been changed for the better, the convertible retains some of the Sebring’s glitches.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Chevrolet Malibu
2. Honda Accord
3. Hyundai Sonata
4. Toyota Camry

Cool Tech:
1. Acoustic laminated glass and sound absorbers.
2. Boston Acoustic speakers.

Looks:
1. New body styling patterned on the 200 concept car from 2009.
2. LED lighting on gauges and displays.
3. Two new color palette additions: Crystal Blue and Deep Auburn.

New for 2013:
1.Previous "S model" is offered as an appearance package on the Touring and Limited editions.
2. Three new exterior colors.

title: 2013 Ford Edge
subTitle: Its looks aren’t edgy, but it edges closer to stylishness than the average boxy people carrier.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Ford Edge
promoTeaser: 2013 Ford Edge
metaTitle: 2013 Ford Edge Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Ford Edge Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Ford’s Edge is all about versatility. It’s about moving beyond the carpool mindset and going for something more appealing to drive. Its looks are on the curvy side, distancing it from the boxy minivan aesthetic, yet it still has the kind of interior space a cargo- and kid-carrying family will appreciate. The Edge can be fitted with a turbocharged four-cylinder or one of two V-6 choices. With the four, fuel economy is 21 mpg in the city and an impressive 30 mpg on the highway, while the V-6s offer 19 mpg in town and 26 or 27 mpg on the highway. All-wheel drive is an option for all models; it cuts fuel economy by about 2 mpg. The Edge offers well-tuned and responsive steering, along with some of the latest in safety technology: roll stability control, side air curtains for the first and second rows of seats, and blind-spot mirrors. A Blind Spot Information System is optional. Ford’s Sync multimedia system and MyFord Touch touchscreen interface are both available on every Edge except for the base model, but prepare for a learning curve. The top-end Edge, the Sport, has the biggest V-6 (305 horsepower) and lots of upscale goodies, including paddle shifters for the six-speed automatic transmission, charcoal leather-trimmed seats with metallic silver inserts, a Sony audio system with HD radio, six-way heated power seats, twenty-inch polished aluminum wheels with black spokes, and chrome oval dual exhaust pipes. It also comes with a $10,000 higher price than the $27,525 of the base Edge, starting at $37,110.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Honda Crosstour
2. Nissan Murano
3.Toyota Venza

Cool Tech:
1. Sync with voice-activated MyFord Touch technology.
2. Blind Spot Information System (BLIS).
3. Active grille shutters that close at higher speeds for better aerodynamics.

Looks
1. New SEL appearance package has twenty-inch machined aluminum wheels, alcantara inserts on seats.
2. Fold-flat front passenger’s seat on the Sport.

New for 2013
1. Newest version of Sync with MyFord Touch – voice-activated navigation.
2. Sport mode on the six-speed automatic transmission adds more fun to driving.
3. All-wheel drive now available on all models.

title: hatchback
promoTeaserSmall: hatchback
promoTeaser: hatchback
metaTitle: hatchback
metaDescription: hatchback

pageElements.text: What hatchbacks have in common is that they have a door that opens up in back for commodious storage and access, making a two-door car into a three-door and a four-door into a five-door. Most are not only easy to pack but easy to afford.

title: 2013 Ford Flex
subTitle: You can love it or leave it, but there’s no denying that the Ford Flex makes an excellent people-mover for those who want to upgrade from a minivan
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Ford Flex
promoTeaser: 2013 Ford Flex
metaTitle: 2013 Ford Flex Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Ford Flex Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: A redesign for 2013 means the big Flex, while still as flat-topped and slab-sided as before, now has a softer front-end look that brings it more in line with the look of current Fords. The interior has also been redesigned with new instrument clusters. That could help the multipurpose vehicle—more attractive than a minivan, more carlike than an SUV—get some of the sales momentum it has been lacking. Despite its stance as an anti-minivan, the Flex is very family friendly. A new feature for 2013 is a set of inflatable rear seatbelts—belts with airbags inside, an industry first—that can deploy in 40 milliseconds, a boon to those carrying children or older people as passengers. There’s also a choice of second-row buckets or a bench that gives the Flex room for seven. In the excitement department, the Flex’s new V-6 engine makes 287 horsepower and highway mileage of 25 mpg. An optional EcoBoost V-6 turbo makes an invigorating 355 horsepower and gets 23 mpg on the highway. One of the best things about the Flex is how upscale you can make it: the Titanium appearance package has charcoal leather-trimmed seats with perforated gray leather inserts, a wrapped steering wheel with black bezels and a striking set of twenty-inch wheels. But watch out for the rising price as you add on the attractive extras.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Honda Pilot
2. Toyota Highlander
3. Chevrolet Traverse

Cool Tech:
1. Refrigerated console in second row.
2. Inflatable second-row safety belts.
3. Optional power-folding third-row seat.

Looks
1. Titanium package includes black-painted roof, mirror caps, and aluminum wheels.
2. Multi-panel vista roof.

New for 2013
1. Optional rain-sensing wipers and power folding mirrors.
2. Keyless entry/start.
3. 3.5-liter Ti-VCT V-6 engine.

title: 2013 Porsche Cayenne
subTitle: Adding diesel power to the underhood offerings is no mean feat. It’s like a footlong among regular dogs.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Porsche Cayenne
promoTeaser: 2013 Porsche Cayenne
metaTitle: 2013 Porsche Cayenne Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Porsche Cayenne here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: There are six Cayenne models spanning a roughly $60,000 range from lowest sticker price to highest, within which there is astonishing diversity. For example, the top-of-the-line Cayenne Turbo is able to hit a terminal speed of 172 mph. Even the V-6 base model and the new Diesel can tow 7,716 pounds. Every Cayenne has the most amazing brakes you’ll find on an SUV. If Facebook stock’s performance ever matched that of the Cayenne, Mark Zuckerberg could buy Canada. On top of this, the interior is luxurious and the instrument display and center controls would be the envy of many spaceship commanders. The 420 horsepower GTS, with its 4.8-liter V-8, had been the line-up’s newbie, producing 20 horsepower more than the S, but the Diesel came along this fall. It has a 3.0-liter V-6, and although the 240 horsepower doesn’t seem that impressive, there’s plenty of whomp with 406 lb-ft. of torque. Rather than part-time all-wheel drive, the Diesel’s system is permanent. And of course, the S Hybrid achieves the highest efficiency numbers. Adaptive cruise control, lane-change assist, and a backup camera make the Cayenne driver’s life easier. Any complaints? The palette of available colors isn’t as crazy as you find in the sports cars--no lime or orange.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Land Rover Range Rover
2. BMW X5
3. Infiniti QX56

Cool Tech Items:
1. Optional speed limit indicator uses navigation system to informs the driver of speed limits, a handy thing if you miss a sign.
2. Call us lame, but we’re still impressed with a heated steering wheel, and it’s available on all models, standard on the Turbo.
3. Electronic logbook option to the Porsche Command Module lets you record particulars of every trip.

Looks:
1. The optional moonroof is large enough for a lunar rover’s landing pad.
2. Wheels as large as twenty-one inches are available.
3. Roof transportation system can carry 220 pounds.

New for 2013:
1. Diesel power.
2. Washable ski bag is available.
3. Glove compartment is cooled by the air conditioning system.

title: 2013 Honda Accord
subTitle: A new look for an old standby
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Honda Accord
promoTeaser: 2013 Honda Accord
metaTitle: 2013 Honda Accord Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Honda Accord Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Honda Accord has been the most dependably dependable sedan on the market for decades. The 2013 model will be the Accord’s first redesign since 2008, and will feature a coupe model in addition to the familiar sedan. The Accord coupe concept caused a huge stir when it debuted at the 2012 North American International Auto Show, and for good reason. New features include Pandora Internet radio connectivity and available lane departure and forward collision warning. The new Accord will also offer SMS functionality for phones with Bluetooth capability. The Accord’s interior isn’t quite luxurious, but it is functional. That is not to say it is completely devoid of innovation, though. A new feature in the top trim level delivers a push-button start option to this practical commuter car. The redesign should offer some excitement to the brand, and a new reason to buy perhaps the most practical car on the market. The 2013 Accord will earn up to 36 mpg on the highway, not quite on par with competitors. If the Accord’s long-awaited redesign still doesn’t impress you, the plug-in hybrid (PHEV) joins the lineup in New York and California in early 2013.
Fun-O-meter: 5

Competition:
1. Chevrolet Malibu
2. Hyundai Sonata
3. Toyota Camry

Cool Tech:
1. New available safety features like collision warning and blind spot cameras.
2. HondaLink System will offer hands-free access to music.

Looks:
1. New redesign will look more sleek and compact.
2. Retains interior cargo space.

New for 2013:
1. New plug-in hybrid model.
2. Rumored Bluetooth and SMS connectivity.

title: 2013 Honda CR-V
subTitle: A crossover/SUV with everything you expect from a Honda
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Honda CR-V
promoTeaser: 2013 Honda CR-V
metaTitle: 2013 Honda CR-V Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Honda CR-V Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Slightly smaller than previous models, the 2013 CR-V operates a 185-horsepower engine with a five-speed automatic transmission that has been retooled for greater efficiency. The 2013 earns 22 to 23 mpg in the city and 30 to 31 mpg on the highway, a slight uptick that nonetheless pushes it above the 30 mpg benchmark. Honda’s biggest crossover offers 1,500 pounds of towing and 37 cubic feet of cargo space even with the rear seats up, giving it plenty of room for errands around town or family road trips. The engine has spirit, and the car’s steering and handling are assets, especially for its size. Honda didn’t do much to change the CR-V’s interior or exterior styling, but that might be because the existing model worked fairly well. The CR-V has intuitive controls, though it’s navigation system could use an update. Right in the middle of Honda’s price range, the CR-V has a base price topping out just above $30,000. This also makes it one of the cheaper utilitarian vehicles on the market, easily beating the price of larger SUVs while still providing impressive capacity.

Competition:
1. Ford Escape
2. Chevrolet Equinox
3. Kia Sportage

Cool Tech:
1. Rearview camera with parking guidelines.
2. Rear DVD player.

Looks:
1. Leather trim on interior.
2. Power moonroof and rear privacy glass.

New for 2013:
1. Marginally improved fuel efficiency.
2. Slightly shorter in length and height.

title: 2013 Honda Ridgeline
subTitle: The Ridgeline may not look good, but it makes up for it under the skin
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Honda Ridgeline
promoTeaser: 2013 Honda Ridgeline
metaTitle: 2013 Honda Ridgeline Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Honda Ridgeline Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Honda Ridgeline is Honda’s somewhat strange stab at a pickup truck. Strange, of course, does not always mean bad. The Ridgeline’s design is its most unusual feature, giving it the air of an SUV with a chunk missing. It bucks traditional pickup build by being the only mid-size truck on the market with a cab and truck bed built in one piece, meaning that the sections don’t bounce around separately while driving. This gives the Ridgeline a smoother ride than many pickups, while still maintaining the convenience of an open-bed truck. It is, however, significantly more expensive than many of its competitors, with a base price range in the $30,000s. The Ridgeline has a 250-horsepower V-6 engine and is rated to tow 5,000 pounds. With four doors and two rows of seats, the Ridgeline can seat five, though the cabin is not appointed quite as well as the rest of Honda’s fleet. As if the Ridgeline needed any more cargo space, there is a lockable in-bed trunk with 8.5 cubic feet of storage for anything you don’t want flying around the truck bed. As always with Honda, the Ridgeline is reliable and drives well.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competition:
1. Chevrolet Colorado
2. GMC Canyon
3. Nissan Frontier

Cool Tech:
1. Unibody design makes for smoother, quieter ride.
2. Navigation system with voice recognition and hands-free phone link available on some models.
3. Tow rated for 5,000 pounds.

Looks:
1. Odd exterior styling.
2. Tailgate opens down or to the side for easy trunk access.
3. Lockable in-bed trunk.

title: 2013 Jaguar XF
subTitle: Vivacious, bubbly and, in certain situations, startlingly fast.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Jaguar XF
promoTeaser: 2013 Jaguar XF
metaTitle: 2013 Jaguar XF Buyer's Guide - Jean Know Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Jaguar XF Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Driving a Jaguar XF is like taking a walk on the wild side without the risk of getting burned. Here is an attractive sedan that has plenty of practical attributes.  It has had its growing pains in the last few seasons due to fussy controls, a batty information and entertainment system, and quality concerns, but it seems to be back on track as it spruces up its act for 2013 with the addition of all-wheel drive and two new powertrains. The new, 240-horsepower turbocharged engine gets 29 mpg on the highway, which isn’t too bad for a mid-size sedan. For those with a need for speed, there is the option of the new supercharged V-6, which replaces a five-liter V-8. What is neat about the V-6 is that not only does it come with Jaguar’s own all-wheel drive system, but it is also pretty fuel-efficient. If you want to throw caution to the wind completely, give the performance XFR a whirl, which puts the "R" in "racy." If you still aren’t sold, just remember that the beauty of a Jaguar sedan is that you can pretty much take it anywhere, somewhat like a perfect little black dress that can be dressed up or dressed down.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Audi A6
2. Acura RL
3. BMW 5 Series

Cool Tech:
1. Premium audio system by Meridian.

Looks:
1. Air vents open and move automatically when car is started.
2. More muscular appearance.
3. The interior blends aluminum, wood trim, and leather.

New for 2013
1. Upgraded navigation system for your driving convenience.
2. Two new engine options include a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine and a 3.0-liter supercharged V-6.
3. The XF gets all-wheel drive.

title: 2012 Lamborghini Aventador
subTitle: The boldest thing on four wheels
promoTeaserSmall: 2012 Lamborghini Aventador
promoTeaser: 2012 Lamborghini Aventador
metaTitle: 2012 Lamborghini Aventador Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2012 Lamborghini Aventador Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Lamborghini Aventador is one of the most expensive cars money can buy. As if that wasn’t enough to recommend it, it is also an absolutely stunning automobile and has an advertised top speed of 217 miles per hour. The Aventador’s exterior styling is unlike anything else in showrooms. Immediately recognizable as a Lamborghini, the aggressive front end transitions seamlessly into an aerodynamic roof and back end. The car’s most striking features are its two jack-knife doors, which immediately announce the Aventador as an exotic car – though not without giving it a Batmobile-like air. Much of the body, including the passenger cabin, is constructed out of weight-shaving carbon fiber.  This helps the V-12 engine make the trip from 0 to 60 mph in less than three seconds.  The interior is modern to the first degree, with a digital dashboard and large, center-mounted navigation system. The cabin comes in either monotone or two-tone leather. With thirteen exterior paint colors and an Ad Personam program that allows buyers to completely personalize their cars, the Aventador gives you everything you could ask for and more.
Fun-O-Meter: 10

Competition:
1. Ferrari 458
2. Lexus LFA
3. Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG

Cool Tech:
1. 700-horsepower engine.
2. Push-button start.
3. Blistering acceleration, 0 to 60 mph in 2.9 seconds.

Looks:
1. Thirteen exterior colors.
2. Unforgettable exterior design.
3. All-leather interior.

New for 2013:
1. Optional transparent engine cover.
2. Choice of three colors for brake calipers.
3. Thirteen exterior paint colors and single color or two-tone leather interiors.

title: 2013 Maserati GranTurismo
subTitle: A beautiful speedster for four
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Maserati GranTurismo
promoTeaser: 2013 Maserati GranTurismo
metaTitle: 2013 Maserati GranTurismo Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Maserati GranTurismo Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Maserati GranTurismo may be less expensive than a Ferrari or Lamborghini, but that doesn’t mean it’s low class. Clocking in above $100,000, the GranTurismo makes a statement and it makes a fast one. With a top speed of about 177 miles per hour (or 285 kph, if you ask the Italians ) this sporty four-passenger won’t leave you breathing someone else’s exhaust.  The GranTurismo manages 20 mpg on the highway – nothing to brag about but not a deal breaker either, especially compared to similarly mediocre performance from its competitors. The GranTurismo is available as a coupe or a soft top convertible. The interior is luxuriously appointed in leather – available in ten colors ranging from beige to bright red or deep blue – with chrome accents and a standard Bose Surround Sound audio system. The GranTurismo’s V-8 engine was engineered by Ferrari, so it should be plenty loud and fast enough to keep drivers happy. Though it’s a little too chubby to really compete with the best of the best, the GranTurismo is an excellent vehicle for someone looking to add a little comfort to their sports car experience, and it certainly won’t blend in with the crowd.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Aston Martin V8 vantage
2. Bentley Continental GT
3. Jaguar XKR-S

Cool Tech:
1. Ferrari engineered V-8 engine.
2. Standard Bose Surround Sound system.
3. Several selectable drive modes to adapt to driver preferences and driving conditions.

Looks:
1. Dozens of exterior and interior color choices.
2. Good-looking design.
3. Plush interior.

New for 2013:
1. New Sport model replaces S and S Automatic models.

title: 2012 Maserati Quattroporte
subTitle: Four doors, five seats, and a Ferrari engine – what’s not to like?
promoTeaserSmall: 2012 Maserati Quattroporte
promoTeaser: 2012 Maserati Quattroporte
metaTitle: 2012 Maserati Quattroporte Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2012 Maserati Quattroporte Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Maserati Quattroporte is a beautiful melding of the fine engineering and speed of a Maserati with the practicality of a sedan with room for your luggage. This five-seater is propelled by a Ferrari-engineered V-8 engine that allows it to reach speeds of almost 170 miles per hour. The Quattroporte handles curvy roads like a much smaller car, but the cabin still feels roomy and luxurious. The leather seats can come in one of ten colors, and with a similarly wide selection of exterior colors and Maserati’s extensive personalization options, the Quattroporte can be exactly the sedan you’ve always dreamed of. It goes without saying that this doesn’t all come for free. The Quattroporte lives in the $130,000 range, and with its unimpressive gas mileage (12 mpg in the city, 19 on the highway) the Quattroporte would be expensive as an everyday car. However, the fuel economy tradeoff is one you’ll make with any performance automobile, and while it would be easy to double your fuel economy by driving a Honda, the accompanying decline in driving enjoyment would be far more painful than a costly trip to the pump.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competition:
1. Aston Martin Rapide
2. Jaguar XJ
3. Mercedes-Benz CLS-class

Cool Tech:
1. Standard navigation system with iPod connect.
2. Ferrari engineered V-8 engine.
3. S model can go 177 mph.

Looks:
1. Available pull-down tables for rear seats.
2. Available power sunroof.
3. Sleek, sexy exterior design.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class
subTitle: Less roomy and more expensive than the E-Class, but you can’t take your eyes off it.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class
promoTeaser: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: Often imitated, never quite equaled, the CLS has managed to stay ahead of its followers in the swoopy four-door class by offering a nice selection of powertrains and pouring on the technology. To the full complement of active safety and driver-assistance aids, the CLS-Class now has the latest mbrace software as standard. Internet access is a part of that package, including Mercedes-specific apps, and mbrace2 more or less makes your smartphone a remote control device. That starts with locking or unlocking the doors from a distance but extends to “geofencing,” which ensures that your car stays within a prescribed area and under a predetermined maximum speed. Touché, joyriders! But joyriding may be in order because there are three engine choices, starting with the CLS550’s 4.6-liter turbocharged V-8 that produces 402 horsepower. Mercedes-Benz’s 4Matic all-wheel drive system is available. The CLS63 AMG comes with a 5.5-liter turbocharged V-8 producing 518 horsepower. Automatic stop/start, a fuel economy feature, shuts off the engine when the car sits at a stoplight, then refires it when the driver lets off the brake. Not enough output for you? The optional performance package wrings 550 horsepower out of the same engine.
Fun-O-Meter: 8

Competitors:
1. Audi A7
2. BMW 6-series Gran Coupe
3. Jaguar XJ

Cool Tech:
1. Standard lane keeping detects a drifting car and brakes the appropriate wheel to guide you back.
2. Active LED headlights “look” around curves and vary the range of high-beams.
3. Automatic stop/start technology is included with CLS63 AMG.

Looks
1. Nineteen-inch wheels are available.
2. Two matte-finish exterior colors are available.
3. Leather upholstery is available in nine colors.

New for 2013
1. The mbrace2 technology is upgraded to include Internet access.
2. Mbrace2 adds “Control” functionality with geographic restrictions on the car’s travel.
3. Over-the-air diagnostic capabilities are added through mbrace2.

title: 2013 Mercedes-Benz G-Class
subTitle: The over-endowed SUV is further endowed with new safety and tech features, and the AMG version returns
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mercedes-Benz G-Class
promoTeaser: 2013 Mercedes-Benz G-Class
metaTitle: 2013 Mercedes-Benz G-Class Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mercedes-Benz G-Class Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: A problem with the G-Class is the way its invincibility is compromised by old-fashioned elements like hard-to-use door handles and slow-acting steering. Yes, it’s awesomely capable, but it has a cramped backseat. People buy it anyway, and not because of the off-road obstacles it will conquer. Who would take their $113,000 truck out on the Rubicon Trail? Rather, the G-Class has a cool, authentic look that comes from form following function, and makes the driver feel like the hero in an apocalyptic action-adventure film. For 2013, Mercedes-Benz has refreshed the G with new interior appointments. Foremost among them is a freestanding, seven-inch, tablet-style central display unit. There are also steering-wheel-mounted paddle shifters for manual control of the seven-speed automatic transmission. A suite of technological systems is added for parking and blind spot assistance, with adaptive cruise control thrown in for good measure. Outside on the G’s square nose, LED daytime running lights are now in place. The 5.5-liter V-8 in the G550 now produces 388 horsepower. Displacing the same volume, the G63 AMG’s turbocharged V-8 makes 544 horsepower and is equipped with automatic stop/start for fuel economy purposes. Special trim and twenty-inch wheels distinguish the AMG.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Land Rover Range Rover
2. Infinity QX56
3. Lexus LX570

Cool Tech:
1. A two-speed transfer case and three electronically lockable differentials give the G-Class superior off-road ability.
2. The AMG model’s automatic stop/start, a fuel economy feature, shuts off the engine when the car sits at a stoplight, then refires it when the driver releases the brake.
3. Mbrace2 adds telematics functionality for external control of systems via smartphone.

Looks
1. LED daytime running lamps and LED tail lights are now included.
2. Side-mirror caps have LED turn indicators.
3. The AMG’s twenty-inch wheels are available in black.

New for 2013
1. A sleek, freestanding seven-inch flat screen serves as the central display.
2. Parking assistance and adaptive cruise control are added.
3. The G63 AMG’s sophisticated turbocharged V-8 makes 544 horsepower.

title: 2012 Scion xD
subTitle: Smaller, cheaper, and more efficient than the xB
promoTeaserSmall: 2012 Scion xD
promoTeaser: 2012 Scion xD
metaTitle: 2012 Scion xD Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2012 Scion xD here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The xD was Scion’s replacement for the xA, but it looks more like a shrunken version of the utilitarian xB. The xD is about a foot smaller than the xB, and it is not quite as tall or as wide as its sibling.  It also sits on a smaller wheelbase. Despite it’s small size and low weight, the xD doesn’t exactly shoot off the starting blocks. However, the nimbler of Scion’s five-door offerings gets the best fuel mileage of the fleet (excluding outlier Scion iQ) at 33 miles per gallon on the highway.  The xD’s interior isn’t quite spacious, but neither is it cramped. The rear seats fold flat to allow for increased cargo space. Like all Scions, the xD’s list of add-ons is almost overwhelming, and goes far beyond usual offerings of upgraded wheels and window tints. With available accessories like shocks, mufflers, and brakes, and a base price at $16,000, the xD is perfect for an enthusiast on a budget. Don’t wait too long, though. There is talk of replacing the xD with an all new model as part of Scion’s never ending crusade for novelty.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Chevrolet Sonic
2. Honda Fit
3. Kia Soul

Cool Tech:
1. Standard Pioneer audio system.
2. Many available mechanical accessories.
3. Available factory navigation system.

Looks:
1. Sport seats for driver and passenger.
2. Underfloor storage in cargo area.
3.Orange backlighting on instrument panel.

title: 2013 Mini Cooper Coupe
subTitle: A Mini with a different look
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mini Cooper Coupe
promoTeaser: 2013 Mini Cooper Coupe
metaTitle: 2013 Mini Cooper Coupe Buyer's Guide - Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: 2013 Mini Cooper Coupe Buyer's Guide

pageElements.text: The Mini Coupe combines the classic lower half of a Mini – bulldog grille and large round headlights – with a very distinctive and somewhat surprising top half that gives the Coupe its speedy look. The front windshield is pushed back, and the roof is lower than other Minis, but the real difference is in the back end. The Mini is already spritely, but this version looks even more quick and maneuverable. Better yet, it actually is quick and maneuverable, and certainly won’t bore you. The John Cooper Works model is the most powerful, but also the most expensive, though with strong fuel economy, you could make up the difference in time.  Like the rest of the Mini family, this two-seater features sport seats and a very large, center-mounted speedometer. The passenger cabin has a trapdoor to the trunk in case you’re transporting something too long for the tight cargo space, and a center armrest can come equipped with a built-in iPhone charging cable. The best thing about the Coupe may be its price. With even the most expensive model barely topping $30,000, the Coupe easily beats the price of luxury competitors but still has spunk.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competition:
1. Audi TT
2. Hyundai Veloster
3. Scion tC

Cool Tech:
1. Impressive gas mileage up to 37 mpg highway.
2. Available armrest with iPhone cable.
3. Navigation and sound system screen mounted in speedometer.

Looks:
1. Distinctive top half and body style.
2. Available racing stripes.
3. Two-tone paint job, one color for body another for roof.

New for 2013:
1. Standard Bluetooth connectivity.
2. Available Sirius Satellite Radio.

title: 2012 Ford Fiesta SE
promoTeaserSmall: I admire the Fiesta’s zoom—and its low price.
promoTeaser: I admire the Fiesta’s zoom—and its low price.
metaTitle: 2012 Ford Fiesta SE - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: My short, sweet look at the 2012 Ford Fiesta SE here on Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The 2012 Ford Fiesta SE chilled in my driveway, but even a cold snap couldn't cut the level of cuteness of this small car. The Fiesta SE in the video is a sedan, but the hatchback is even cuter.
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/W3yhffOMnco" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

But it's not all about the looks: the Fiesta is fun to drive, even though it is a low-priced subcompact. Both hatchback and sedan versions are powered by a 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine. Fuel economy hits the current holy grail of 40 mpg on the highway if you get the SFE package, which revises the setup of the engine and transmission and includes low-rolling-resistance tires to add fuel economy.

The Fiesta gets some of its fun quotient from the fact that Ford kept the suspension calibration of the European-market Fiesta when bringing this car onto the U.S. market. Its competitors include the Chevrolet Sonic, Honda Fit, Hyundai Accent, and Nissan Versa, so it's a crowded field, but the Fiesta holds its own.

title: 2012 Jeep Grand Cherokee Altitude 4x4
promoTeaserSmall: Jean parks the Grand Cherokee in the bucolic back forty.
promoTeaser: Jean parks the Grand Cherokee in the bucolic back forty.
metaTitle: 2012 Jeep Grand Cherokee Altitude 4x4 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Check out Jean's review of the 2012 Jeep Grand Cherokee Altitude 4x4 here on Jean's Driveway, only on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The mid-size Jeep Grand Cherokee Altitude SUV is the sort of vehicle that most people think of when they think of an SUV, and then some. The Altitude name was chosen from among more than 100,000 entries in a Jeep consumer contest called Name My Ride. The prize was, of course, a $40,000 Grand Cherokee.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/0KUSkUDOS3w" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

This vehicle's Altitude package and options add more than $10,000 to the base price of the Grand Cherokee: a Grand Cherokee Laredo 4x4 starts at $30,120 including destination, and this Altitude costs $42,200 including destination. Of course, for that money it's well equipped, with a $6,600 trim package, a $1,695 Hemi 5.7-liter V-8 engine, an $895 power sunroof, a $495 power liftgate, a $2,200 options package that includes keyless entry and SiriusXM satellite radio, and a $395 UConnect communications system.

Cosmetic touches with the Altitude trim package include a blacked-out exterior with a black glossy grille surround and a platinum chrome mesh grille. The 20-inch wheels and tires add to the look. Leather-trimmed seats (the front seats are heated), plus a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shifter complete the look.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Suburban
subTitle: There ain’t nothing like the real thing.
promoTeaserSmall: There ain’t nothing like the real thing.
promoTeaser: There ain’t nothing like the real thing.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Suburban Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Suburban here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Suburban is sui generis: not a minivan or a work truck, not an SUV, not a station wagon. Call it the Shaquille O’Neal of vehicles: it’s a behemoth, yes, but one that overflows with personality and charm despite its eighteen-plus-foot length.  Who doesn’t like the Suburban? It has not been the butt of hostility the way the Hummer, for example, has been. And even though there has been a Suburban on the market for nearly eight decades, no committee has turned it into a Suburbanette or taken it off the job it is on earth to do: haul people and stuff capably. If you’re shopping for one, know that you can choose from three V-8 engines, and in half-ton or three-quarter-ton versions. Active Fuel Management is on hand to bust that eight down to four cylinders when cruising, to save on gasoline, and E85 can be used. But you don’t care about that as much as two other numbers: how much cargo, and how many people? The answers are: 138 cubic feet, and nine people. There are also comfort features on board, including a second- and third-row DVD system, touchscreen navigation, a backup camera, and heated seats in the front two rows. So what are you waiting for? Saddle up, remember to fuel up-- and off you go.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Lincoln Navigator
2. Ford Expedition
3. GMC Yukon XL
4. Nissan Armada

Cool Tech Items:
1. Rear DVD entertainment system with third-row DVD screen, part of the Sun, Entertainment and Destinations package.

Looks:
1. Three new metallic paint colors; Champagne now, Concord and Blue Ray coming later in model year.

New for 2013:
1. Powertrain grade braking now available when transmission is in normal mode (doesn’t have to be on tow/haul setting).

title: 2013 Chevrolet Silverado
subTitle: Rock-steady pickup from the Like a Rock brand.
promoTeaserSmall: Rock-steady pickup from the Like a Rock brand.
promoTeaser: Rock-steady pickup from the Like a Rock brand.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Silverado Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Silverado here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The Chevrolet Silverado pickup truck, like the workers who will buy it, is nothing if not versatile. It can be configured in an amazing number of variations, including five trim levels, a choice of three bed lengths up to eight feet, three cab sizes up to crew cab, rear- or four-wheel drive, and five V-6 or V-8 engines—plus there’s even a hybrid. Fuel economy may not be what a full-size pickup is about, but the Silverado 1500 Hybrid can tow 6,100 pounds while getting 23 mpg on the highway—the eco equivalent of bringing home the bacon and frying it up in a pan, we guess. There’s also a conventionally V-8-powered Silverado, the XFE, that offers 22 highway mpg thanks to “aerodynamic enhancements.” New for 2013 is powertrain grade braking for models with the six-speed automatic transmission, which downshifts the transmission to cool down the brakes on those long downhill stretches. Also, there are two new metallic exterior colors, Deep Ruby and Blue Topaz. But decorative touches are a minor point. GM leaves no doubt about what kind of buyer it’s aiming this truck at, using terms like “broad shouldered” and “chiseled”—to describe the truck, not the customer, but chances are, the descriptors fit both.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Ford F-150
2. GMC Sierra
3. Ram 1500
4. Nissan Titan

Cool Tech Items:
1. Optional rear backup camera.
2. Powertrain grade braking downshifts transmission on downhill driving to save the brakes.

Looks:
1. Chrome bumper standard on three trim levels.
2. Grab-style door handles good for glove wearers.

New for 2013:
1. Ruby Red and Blue Topaz metallic paint colors added.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Corvette
subTitle: Six decades of wind in the hair and a song in the heart.
promoTeaserSmall: Six decades of wind in the hair and a song in the heart.
promoTeaser: Six decades of wind in the hair and a song in the heart.
metaTitle: 2013 Chevrolet Corvette Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Chevrolet Corvette here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Yes, it has been sixty fun-filled years since the first Chevrolet Corvette hit American roads. Making no concessions to this late-middle-age number, in 2013 Chevrolet is selling the fastest convertible in the history of the bow-tie brand, the 427 convertible. With its carbon fiber body parts and 505-horsepower 7.0-liter V-8, it’s pretty much a droptop version of the Corvette Z06. GM is calling it a Collector Edition, so keep that in mind. The Z06 coupe comes in a limited Carbon edition that has many of the styling features of its more powerful ZR1 sibling. Speaking of the ZR1, the top Corvette’s supercharged V-8 makes 638 horsepower and lets the Vette go north of 200 mph. The big story for 2013, in addition to the last year the current-generation C6 Corvette is in production, is the Sixtieth Anniversary appearance package. It’s a pretty classy-looking Arctic White exterior with two shades of blue on the leather-wrapped interior. An optional graphics package shouts a bit more loudly about the anniversary, and naturally there is badging inside and out to make this package more special. Corvette buyers looking for something a little less pricey may prefer the lower-frills Grand Sport, still with a sub-four-second 0-to-60-mph time close to that of its pricier stablemates. Add to that the base coupe and convertible models, and you’ll see that there’s a Corvette at price points just above $50,000 to a bit over $100,000.
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Competitors:
1. Audi R8
2. Lotus Evora
3. Porsche 911

Cool Tech Items:
1. Carbon fiber body panels, including fenders and hood, on the 427 convertible.
2. Magnetic ride control.

Looks:
1. Sixtieth Anniversary Design package: two-tone blue seating, racing stripes.
2. Lightweight Cup wheels on 427 convertible.

New for 2013:
1. 427 convertible is new model.

title: 2013 Lincoln MKT
subTitle: Three big rows of comfort and luxury for the crossover crowd.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Lincoln MKT
promoTeaser: 2013 Lincoln MKT
metaTitle: 2013 Lincoln MKT -- Buyer's Guide -- JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Learn about the 2013 Lincoln MKT from JeanKnowsCars.Com.

pageElements.text: Lincoln’s 2013 MKT has the same sharp good looks as the rest of Ford’s luxury brand’s lineup. The MKT is the large crossover member of the family, and as such it has the capability to seat up to seven people in comfort. For 2013, Lincoln has added Drive Control and continuously controlled damping, which manage the tradeoff between the ability to handle this big vehicle and the comfort of the people inside. It actually adjusts the suspension twenty times per second to get that job done. The EcoBoost 3.5-liter V-6 engine has been upgraded for 365 horsepower (it was 355 hp last year). Curve control to keep you in charge of this big vehicle when going around curves, plus lane keeping technology, are welcome additions for 2013. The interior has also been refreshed, both cosmetically and with the addition of inflatable rear seatbelts. On the outside, the grille gets the new, somewhat aggressive-looking treatment similar to that of other Lincolns this year, and wheels are available in nineteen- and twenty-inch sizes. Ford’s Sync system is available in an expanded version with WiFi hotspot capability. As you might expect from such a large, luxurious crossover, Lincoln is offering it to the professional-driver market in Livery and Limousine models. But you can get your own and make it your family’s limousine.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Lexus GX460
2. Buick Enclave
3. Volvo XC90

Cool Tech:
1. Curve control.
2. Continuously controlled damping improves ride and handling.
3. Expanded Ford Sync with WiFi hotspot capability.
4. Inflatable rear seatbelts.

Looks:
1. New interior styling.

title: 2013 Lexus ES
subTitle: Suddenly sexy ES gets wowza styling and new hybrid variant
promoTeaserSmall: Suddenly sexy ES gets wowza styling and new hybrid variant
promoTeaser: Suddenly sexy ES gets wowza styling and new hybrid variant
metaTitle: 2013 Lexus ES Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars

pageElements.text: While Lexus’s benign ES sedan has never been a paragon of style or excitement, the popular sedan has helped butter Lexus’s bread since the brand’s humble beginnings by putting quietness, high perceived quality, and a respectable overall luxury experience within reach for many consumers. Enter the redesigned 2013 ES, with suddenly sexy sheetmetal and a larger, scrumptious interior; together, they elevate this model from entry level status to truly desirable in its own right. Highlights of the ES’s exterior include Lexus’s new spindle grille, flanked by predatory headlamps underscored by a row of LED running lamps. The slab-like sides are complimented by side windows outlined in chrome, while ES wraparound LED taillamps dress up the rear. Inside, passengers face a new two-tiered dashboard design with an available navigation system operated by Lexus’s mouse-like Remote Touch interface, while those in back enjoy more than four inches of added legroom. The ES350’s soft-spoken V-6 engine and silky six-speed automatic transmission are largely carryovers from the previous ES350, so don’t expect much of a character change from previous ES models. More significant is the addition of the first-ever hybrid to the ES lineup called ES300h, which swaps the base V-6 for a four-cylinder engine mated to supplemental electric power, resulting in a combined EPA fuel economy rating of 40 miles per gallon.
Fun-O-Meter: 6

Competitors:
1. Acura TL
2. Lincoln MKZ
3. Volvo S60

Cool Tech Items:
1. Enform app suite with Pandora, Facebook, and Yelp apps, among others.
2. Mouse-like Remote Touch control interface.
3. Available 835-watt surround sound audio system with fifteen speakers.

Looks:
1. Spindle-shaped grille and LED running lamps up front.
2. Elegant new proportions with taut sheetmetal.
3. Sexy LED-based taillamps; unique rear styling for hybrid.

New for 2013:
1. All-new design inspired by new GS.
2. More spacious interior with environmentally friendly NuLuxe upholstery standard.
3. New hybrid ES300h model.

title: 2013 Lexus IS
subTitle: Lexus’s tidy BMW 3-Series competitor is handsome, although graying at the temples.
promoTeaserSmall: Lexus’s tidy BMW 3-Series competitor is handsome, although graying at the temples.
promoTeaser: Lexus’s tidy BMW 3-Series competitor is handsome, although graying at the temples.
metaTitle: 2013 Lexus IS Buyer's Guide -  Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Lexus IS here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: Lexuses are not generally seen as overtly sporty automobiles, but the tidy rear-wheel-drive IS sedan is a notable exception. Like its most direct competitor, the BMW 3-Series, the IS is compact inside and out and is tuned to provide a clear connection between the driver and the road. Also like the 3-Series, the IS is available in hardtop convertible form. Both the IS sedan and the IS-C droptop are available with a choice of two engines: one with a miserly 204 horsepower and the other with a gutsier 306 horsepower, while all-wheel drive is offered on sedans as a boon to customers who happen to live where white stuff drops from the sky every now and then. Perched atop the IS range is the brutally fast, sedan-only IS-F, powered by a monstrous 414-horsepower V-8 and riding on a road-scraping suspension. A domed hood, two pairs of vertically stacked tailpipes, a rear spoiler, and aggressively bolstered front seats round out Lexus’s efforts to sportify the IS-F. If that seems interesting but excessive, Lexus makes some of the IS-F’s visual and handling excitement available in an F Sport package for regular IS sedans and convertibles. All that said, the IS has been around for a long time, and next to its competitors, including the redesigned BMW 3-Series and the all-new Cadillac ATS, the 2013 IS feels, well, old. A redesigned IS is expected in 2013 as a 2014 model, but in the meantime, this is as sporty as it gets at the Lexus store.
Fun-O-Meter: 7 (IS); 9 (IS-F)

Competitors:
1. BMW 3-Series
2. Mercedes-Benz C-Class
3. Cadillac ATS

Cool Tech Items:

2. Burly V-8 in IS-F is a masterpiece.
3. Convertible model features retractable hard top.

Looks:
1. Track-bred IS-F model looks as fast as it is.
2. Rear spoiler, grille insert, and matte black wheels with F Sport package.

title: 2013 Toyota Sequoia
subTitle: If you think bigger is better, Toyota’s got a tree—er, truck—for you.
promoTeaserSmall: If you think bigger is better, Toyota’s got a tree—er, truck—for you.
promoTeaser: If you think bigger is better, Toyota’s got a tree—er, truck—for you.

pageElements.text: It’s a little ironic that the huge, gas-swillin’, eight-passenger Toyota Sequoia shares its name with an endangered species of redwood tree, considering that saving trees is generally not the highest priority of most gargant-u-vee customers. Less surprising is that this sport-utility expression of Toyota’s full-sized, San Antonio-built Tundra pickup, is more than pleasant to drive. The massive interior offers plenty of room to spread out, with a max capacity of eight hearty souls. Only one engine, a 381-horsepower V-8, does the tugging, channeling its power through a six-speed automatic, making the towing of a large travel trailer or boat an easy affair. For 2013, not much has been changed or added except for the optional navigation system (which now features Toyota’s new EnTune apps) and a new Blu-ray player for rear-seat entertainment system. Three trim levels remain on the menu: SR5, Limited, and Platinum, the latter the only Toyota other than the pish-posh Land Cruiser to cross the $60K mark. That’s a chunk of change to be sure, but particularly in its lower grades, the Sequoia offers a whole lot of truck for the money, with proven reliability to boot.
Fun-O-Meter: 5

Competitors:
1. Nissan Armada
2. Ford Expedition
3. Chevrolet Tahoe

3. Available blind spot monitor.

2. Available second-row captain’s chairs.
3. Diamond-cut wheels on Platinum model.

title: 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata
subTitle: The long-standing Mazda MX-5 Miata is a sports car for purists.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata
promoTeaser: 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata
metaTitle: 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars
metaDescription: Learn more about the 2013 Mazda MX-5 Miata here at JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: The rear-wheel-drive Mazda MX-5 Miata – which has been around for more than twenty years – stands out as one of the most spirited and affordable sports cars on the market. It charms with its classic roadster styling and engaging performance. It marks the new model year with a restyled front end. The single downfall in the MX-5 Miata is space. Taller drivers may feel cramped with the top up and the narrow two-seat cabin may leave some feeling slightly claustrophobic. The trunk is Lilliputian. The base car comes with a manual-folding soft top; a power-retractable hard top is optional. The power top is the way to go if you live in a cold-weather state. It goes without saying that the MX-5 Miata is a blast to drive, even though the engine puts out a relatively modest amount of power. A 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine delivers 158 horsepower when mated with the optional six-speed automatic transmission. When equipped with the five- or six-speed manual transmission, it produces 167 horsepower. Models with the five-speed manual transmission deliver 22 mpg in city driving and 28 mpg on the highway, according to the EPA. Standard features include air conditioning, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and cloth upholstery. Expect to pay in the neighborhood of around $25,000 for a base model. For many households, this means that the little roadster is an excellent choice for a second car.
Fun-O-Meter: 7

Competitors:
1. Audi TT
2. Mini Cooper Roadster
3. Porsche Boxster
4. Volkwagen Eos

Cool Tech:
1. Nothing noteworthy; pretty old school.

New for 2013:
1. Restyled front end.
2. Base Sport trim gains fog lights.
3. Club model replaces Touring Trim.

title: 2013 Toyota Yaris
subTitle: Toyota’s subcompact appears destined to stay as is for at least another year.
promoTeaserSmall: 2013 Toyota Yaris
promoTeaser: 2013 Toyota Yaris
metaTitle: 2013 Toyota Yaris--Buyer's Guide--Jean Knows Cars

pageElements.text: Toyota has a long history of building truly great cheap cars, but its current entry vehicle, the Yaris, is not destined to be one of them. Introduced last year as all new, the hatchback was more of a “top hat” redesign replacing the previous Yaris’s body but not the low-powered 1.5-liter engine or the somewhat dated four-speed automatic/five-speed manual transmission choices. As a result, the Yaris is underwhelming, especially considering how strong most of its competition—namely the Ford Fiesta, Chevrolet Sonic, Hyundai Accent, and Kia Rio—has become. Not helping its cause is that it falls short of the magic 40-mpg EPA highway rating, which has become something of the gold standard against which tiny cars are measured these days. That said, the Yaris looks reasonably good, especially in five-door SE form, a trim level that also brings with it some effective performance upgrades that liven up the driving experience considerably. The interior is about as fancy as you’d expect at the sub-$15,000 price point, perhaps even less. But the Yaris does appear to have something of an airbag fetish, as no fewer than nine of the inflatables come standard, including a rare-for-the-class driver’s-side knee bag. New for 2013 is the standard fitment of last year’s audio package. Otherwise, it’s more of the same.

title: Texting and Driving: The Anti-Text Battle Continues
subTitle: Experts differ on how to get people to stop doing it, but anti-text sentiment continues to grow.
promoTitle: Texting and Driving: The Anti-Text Battle Continues
promoTeaserSmall: Experts differ on how to get people to stop doing it, but anti-text sentiment continues to grow.
promoTeaser: Experts differ on how to get people to stop doing it, but anti-text sentiment continues to grow.
metaTitle: Texting and Driving: The Anti-Text Battle Continues - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Texting and Driving: The Anti-Text Battle Continues. Learn about the latest intelligence on texting while driving at JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Despite the fact that I grew up just outside of Detroit, I was never particularly infatuated with cars. It wasn't until I headed to Washington, D.C., and began working for an environmental trade journal that I got an up close and personal look at what it takes to design an automobile. My first articles focused on efforts by legislators to make once heavily polluting cars run cleaner. When I moved back to Michigan, that became my focus as I contributed extensively to the Detroit bureaus of both the New York Times and Newsweek. I became fascinated by how the automobile impacts so many aspects of our lives and reflects our styles and preferences. Over the past two dozen years as a freelancer, I've covered the auto industry for a wide variety of publications, including Popular Mechanics, Scientific American, iVillage, Automotive News, Ad Age, Hemispheres, Technology Review, and AARP. I've also contributed pieces on air to public radio. My coverage has focused on such issues as the ways domestic automakers will respond to increasingly tough mandates for fuel-efficient cars while still designing vehicles that appeal to consumers, and my firsthand—and slightly scary—experience driving an autonomous car. But my stories are less about the vehicle than the person driving it. I'm most intrigued by the way people shape cars and cars shape those who drive them.

pageElements.text: There's no doubt that texting while driving is hazardous to the health of both drivers and others around them. That explains why thirty-nine states and the District of Columbia have enacted laws banning the practice. Now the question is: how effective have those laws been in deterring the behavior?

First, let's underline the problem, although we're sure you are already well aware that texting while driving is a very bad idea. Drivers who text while driving are six times more likely to crash than those who don't, according to a 2009 study by the University of Utah. It's difficult to determine precisely how many crashes are the direct result of texting and driving, since motorists are reluctant to admit that was the cause. But the National Safety Council found that in 2010, three percent of all crashes involved texting and driving, while 21 percent of crashes involved talking on a cell phone. Although that number may seem small, "that risk didn't exist ten years [ago], so this is a big deal," said Dave Teater, the National Safety Council's senior director of transportation initiatives.

Washington State was the first to ban texting while driving, in January 2008. The penalties for violating the law vary widely, as does the enforcement. The state of Wisconsin assesses a fine of up to $400 for the first offense, while in Kentucky a first offense carries only a $25 fine. The state of New York has issued 20,000 tickets for texting while driving, but others say the laws are often difficult to enforce. A 2010 study by the Highway Loss Data Institute found no decrease in crash risk when laws against handheld cell phones were enacted. "We don't see any evidence that texting bans are likely to make a difference in reducing crashes," said Russ Rader, a spokesman for the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

But Russ Martin, a AAA spokesman, disagrees. "We know these laws have a significant impact on driving behavior," he says, pointing to laws mandating seatbelt use and drunk driving prohibitions as examples. He expects that the laws on texting and driving will ultimately have the same deterring effect, although he acknowledges that identifying drivers who text, then proving it in court, continues to be challenging.

Scott Kristiansen, a sergeant with the Buffalo Grove Police Department in Buffalo Grove, Illinois, knows that first hand. His state prohibits any use of electronics while driving, including texting. He says it's often difficult to see if someone is texting in a car, so he and his colleagues employ covert methods, such as having officers stand at street corners dressed as solicitors and watch people in their cars as they approach the intersection. Another tactic officers use is sitting up high in unmarked pickup trucks, from which they can look down to catch violators in their cars. He says that, as more people realize there are undercover police officers on the corners, it's likely many will change their texting behaviors.

Rader says that crash avoidance technologies being used by automakers will do far more to prevent crashes than laws banning texting while driving. One such system, forward collision warning, detects potential hazards ahead and can automatically brake if the driver doesn't react to a signal. Many car companies offer this technology under various names. Among them are Ford, Honda, Nissan, Mercedes-Benz, Toyota, and Volvo. Rader says the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety plans to reward manufacturers that have this available in its safety ratings, and indeed the IIHS already provides a searchable list of automakers and shows which cars have which of six forms of safety technology, including forward collision warning.

Martin agrees that these technologies could be helpful and says there is no single solution. "Texting while driving is so ingrained in American culture. It's not a surprise people are doing it while driving," he says. He says a multi-pronged effort, involving driver education and strong enforcement of the law, will be the best way to prevent the practice. And these days, with everyone from AT&T to the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons telling people to put the cell phone down and stop texting while driving, Martin just might get his wish.
